books.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:1
verses.text: On the Duties of the Clergy Chapter I.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:2
verses.text: A Bishop's special office is to teach; St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:3
verses.text: Ambrose himself, however, has to learn in order that he may teach; or rather has to teach what he has not learnt; at any rate learning and teaching with himself must go on together.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:5
verses.text: I think I shall not seem to be taking too much on myself, if, in the midst of my children, I yield to my desire to teach, seeing that the master of humility himself has said: "Come, ye children, hearken unto me: I will teach you the fear of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:6
verses.text: Wherein one may observe both the humility and the grace of his reverence for God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:7
verses.text: For in saying "the fear of the Lord," which seems to be common to all, he has described the chief mark of reverence for God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:8
verses.text: As, however, fear itself is the beginning of wisdom and the source of blessedness—for they that fear the Lord are blessed—he has plainly marked himself out as the teacher for instruction in wisdom, and the guide to the attainment of blessedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:10
verses.text: We therefore, being anxious to imitate his reverence for God, and not without justification in dispensing grace, deliver to you as to children those things which the Spirit of Wisdom has imparted to him, and which have been made clear to us through him, and learnt by sight and by example.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:11
verses.text: For we can no longer now escape from the duty of teaching which the needs of the priesthood have laid upon us, though we tried to avoid it: "For God gave some, apostles; and some, prophets; and some, evangelists; and some, pastors and teachers".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:13
verses.text: I do not therefore claim for myself the glory of the apostles (for who can do this save those whom the Son of God Himself has chosen?); nor the grace of the prophets, nor the virtue of the evangelists, nor the cautious care of the pastors.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:14
verses.text: I only desire to attain to that care and diligence in the sacred writings, which the Apostle has placed last amongst the duties of the saints; and this very thing I desire, so that, in the endeavour to teach, I may be able to learn.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:15
verses.text: For one is the true Master, Who alone has not learnt, what He taught all; but men learn before they teach, and receive from Him what they may hand on to others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:17
verses.text: But not even this was the case with me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:18
verses.text: For I was carried off from the judgment seat, and the garb [infulis] of office, to enter on the priesthood, and began to teach you, what I myself had not yet learnt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:19
verses.text: So it happened that I began to teach before I began to learn.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 1:20
verses.text: Therefore I must learn and teach at the same time, since I had no leisure to learn before.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:2
verses.text: Manifold dangers are incurred by speaking; the remedy for which Scripture shows to consist in silence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:4
verses.text: Now what ought we to learn before everything else, but to be silent, that we may be able to speak? lest my voice should condemn me, before that of another acquit  me; for it is written: "By thy words thou shalt be condemned".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:5
verses.text: What need is there, then, that thou shouldest hasten to undergo the danger of condemnation by speaking, when thou canst be more safe by keeping silent? How many have I seen to fall into sin by speaking, but scarcely one by keeping silent; and so it is more difficult to know how to keep silent than how to speak.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:6
verses.text: I know that most persons speak because they do not know how to keep silent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:7
verses.text: It is seldom that any one is silent even when speaking profits him nothing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:8
verses.text: He is wise, then, who knows how to keep silent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:9
verses.text: Lastly, the Wisdom of God said: "The Lord hath given to me the tongue of learning, that I should know when it is good to speak".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:10
verses.text: Justly, then, is he wise who has received of the Lord to know when he ought to speak.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:11
verses.text: Wherefore the Scripture says well: "A wise man will keep silence until there is opportunity".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:13
verses.text: Therefore the saints of the Lord loved to keep silence, because they knew that a man's voice is often the utterance of sin, and a man's speech is the beginning of human error.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:14
verses.text: Lastly, the Saint of the Lord said: "I said, I will take heed to my ways, that I offend not in my tongue".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:15
verses.text: For he knew and had read that it was a mark of the divine protection for a man to be hid from the scourge of his own tongue, and the witness of his own conscience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:16
verses.text: We are chastised by the silent reproaches of our thoughts, and by the judgment of conscience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:17
verses.text: We are chastised also by the lash of our own voice, when we say things whereby our soul is mortally injured, and our mind is sorely wounded.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:18
verses.text: But who is there that has his heart clean from the impurities of sin, and does not offend in his tongue? And so, as he saw there was no one who could keep his mouth free from evil speaking, he laid upon himself the law of innocency by a rule of silence, with a view to avoiding by silence that fault which he could with difficulty escape in speaking.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:20
verses.text: Let us hearken, then, to the master of precaution: "I said, I will take heed to my ways;" that is, "I said to myself: in the silent biddings of my thoughts, I have enjoined upon myself, that I should take heed to my ways".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:21
verses.text: Some ways there are which we ought to follow; others as to which we ought to take heed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:22
verses.text: We must follow the ways of the Lord, and take heed to our own ways, lest they lead us into sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:23
verses.text: One can take heed if one is not hasty in speaking.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:24
verses.text: The law says: "Hear, O Israel, the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:25
verses.text: It said not: "Speak," but "Hear".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:26
verses.text: Eve fell because she said to the man what she had not heard from the Lord her God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:27
verses.text: The first word from God says to thee: Hear! If thou hearest, take heed to thy ways; and if thou hast fallen, quickly amend thy way.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:28
verses.text: For: "Wherein does a young man amend his way; except in taking heed to the word of the Lord?" Be silent therefore first of all, and hearken, that thou fail not in thy tongue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:29
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:30
verses.text: It is a great evil that a man should be condemned by his own mouth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:31
verses.text: Truly, if each one shall give account for an idle word, how much more for words of impurity and shame? For words uttered hastily are far worse than idle words.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 2:32
verses.text: If, therefore, an account is demanded for an idle word, how much more will punishment be exacted for impious language?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:2
verses.text: Silence should not remain unbroken, nor should it arise from idleness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:3
verses.text: How heart and mouth must be guarded against inordinate affections.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:5
verses.text: What then? Ought we to be dumb? Certainly not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:6
verses.text: For: "there is a time to keep silence and a time to speak".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:7
verses.text: If, then, we are to give account for an idle word, let us take care that we do not have to give it also for an idle silence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:8
verses.text: For there is also an active silence, such as Susanna's was, who did more by keeping silence than if she had spoken.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:9
verses.text: For in keeping silence before men she spoke to God, and found no greater proof of her chastity than silence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:10
verses.text: Her conscience spoke where no word was heard, and she sought no judgment for herself at the hands of men, for she had the witness of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:11
verses.text: She therefore desired to be acquitted by Him, Who she knew could not be deceived in any way.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:12
verses.text: Yea, the Lord Himself in the Gospel worked out in silence the salvation of men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:13
verses.text: David rightly therefore enjoined on himself not constant silence, but watchfulness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:15
verses.text: Let us then guard our hearts, let us guard our mouths.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:16
verses.text: Both have been written about.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:17
verses.text: In this place we are bidden to take heed to our mouth; in another place thou art told: "Keep thy heart with all diligence".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:18
verses.text: If David took heed, wilt thou not  take heed? If Isaiah had unclean lips—who said: "Woe is me, for I am undone, for I am a man, and have unclean lips"—if a prophet of the Lord had unclean lips, how shall we have them clean?  11.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:19
verses.text: But for whom was it written, unless it was for each one of us: "Hedge thy possession about with thorns, and bind up thy silver and gold, and make a door and a bar for thy mouth, and a yoke and a balance for thy words"? Thy possession is thy mind, thy gold thy heart, thy silver thy speech: "The words of the Lord are pure words, as silver tried in the fire".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:20
verses.text: A good mind is also a good possession.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:21
verses.text: And, further, a pure inner life is a valuable possession.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:22
verses.text: Hedge in, then, this possession of thine, enclose it with thought, guard it with thorns, that is, with pious care, lest the fierce passions of the flesh should rush upon it and lead it captive, lest strong emotions should assault it, and, overstepping their bounds, carry off its vintage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:23
verses.text: Guard thy inner self.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:24
verses.text: Do not neglect or contemn it as though it were worthless, for it is a valuable possession; truly valuable indeed, for its fruit is not perishable and only for a time, but is lasting and of use for eternal salvation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:25
verses.text: Cultivate, therefore, thy possession, and let it be thy tilling ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:27
verses.text: Bind up thy words that they run not riot, and grow wanton, and gather up sins for themselves in too much talking.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:28
verses.text: Let them be rather confined, and held back within their own banks.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:29
verses.text: An overflowing river quickly gathers mud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:30
verses.text: Bind up also thy meaning; let it not be left slack and unchecked, lest it be said of thee: "There is no healing balsam, nor oil, nor bandage to apply".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:31
verses.text: Sobriety of mind has its reins, whereby it is directed and guided.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:33
verses.text: Let there be a door to thy mouth, that it may be shut when need arises, and let it be carefully barred, that none may rouse thy voice to anger, and thou pay back abuse with abuse.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:34
verses.text: Thou hast heard it read to-day: "Be ye angry and sin not".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:35
verses.text: Therefore although we are angry (this arising from the motions of our nature, not of our will), let us not utter with our mouth one evil word, lest we fall into sin; but let there be a yoke and a balance to thy words, that is, humility and moderation, that thy tongue may be subject to thy mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 3:36
verses.text: Let it be held in check with a tight rein; let it have its own means of restraint, whereby it can be recalled to moderation; let it utter words tried by the scales of justice, that there may be seriousness in our meaning, weight in our speech, and due measure in our words.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:2
verses.text: The same care must be taken that our speech proceed not from evil passions, but from good motives; for here it is that the devil is especially on the watch to catch us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:4
verses.text: If any one takes heed to this, he will be mild, gentle, modest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:5
verses.text: For in guarding his mouth, and restraining his tongue, and in not speaking before examining, pondering, and weighing his words—as to whether this should be said, that should be answered, or whether it be a suitable time for this remark—he certainly is practising modesty, gentleness, patience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:6
verses.text: So he will not burst out into speech through displeasure or anger, nor give sign of any passion in his words, nor proclaim that the flames of lust are burning in his language, or that the incentives of wrath are present in what he says.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:7
verses.text: Let him act thus for fear that his words, which ought to grace his inner life, should at the last plainly show and prove that there is some vice in his morals.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:9
verses.text: For then especially does the enemy lay his plans, when he sees passions engendered in us; then he supplies tinder; then he lays snares.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:10
verses.text: Wherefore the prophet says not without cause, as we heard read to-day: "Surely He hath delivered me from the snare of the hunter and from the hard word".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:11
verses.text: Symmachus said this means "the word of provocation;" others "the word that brings disquiet".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:12
verses.text: The snare of the enemy is our speech—but that itself is also just as much an enemy to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:13
verses.text: Too often we say something that our foe takes hold of, and whereby he wounds us as though by our own sword.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:14
verses.text: How far better it is to perish by the sword of others than by our own!  16.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:15
verses.text: Accordingly the enemy tests our arms and clashes together his weapons.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:16
verses.text: If he sees that I am disturbed, he implants the points of his darts, so as to raise a crop of quarrels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:17
verses.text: If I utter an unseemly word, he sets his snare.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:18
verses.text: Then he puts before me the opportunity for revenge as a bait, so that in desiring to be revenged, I may put myself in the snare, and draw the death-knot tight for myself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 4:19
verses.text: If any one feels this enemy is  near, he ought to give greater heed to his mouth, lest he make room for the enemy; but not many see him.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:2
verses.text: We must guard also against a visible enemy when he incites us by silence; by the help of which alone we can escape from those greater than ourselves, and maintain that humility which we must display towards all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:4
verses.text: But we must also guard against him who can be seen, and who provokes us, and spurs us on, and exasperates us, and supplies what will excite us to licentiousness or lust.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:5
verses.text: If, then, any one reviles us, irritates, stirs us up to violence, tries to make us quarrel; let us keep silence, let us not be ashamed to become dumb.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:6
verses.text: For he who irritates us and does us an injury is committing sin, and wishes us to become like himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:8
verses.text: Certainly if thou art silent, and hidest thy feelings, he is wont to say: "Why are you silent? Speak if you dare; but you dare not, you are dumb, I have made you speechless".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:9
verses.text: If thou art silent, he is the more excited.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:10
verses.text: He thinks himself beaten, laughed at, little thought of, and ridiculed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:11
verses.text: If thou answerest, he thinks he has become the victor, because he has found one like himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:12
verses.text: For if thou art silent, men will say: "That man has been abusive, but this one held him in contempt".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:13
verses.text: If thou return the abuse, they will say: "Both have been abusive".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:14
verses.text: Both will be condemned, neither will be acquitted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:15
verses.text: Therefore it is his object to irritate, so that I may speak and act as he does.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:16
verses.text: But it is the duty of a just man to hide his feelings and say nothing, to preserve the fruit of a good conscience, to trust himself rather to the judgment of good men than to the insolence of a calumniator, and to be satisfied with the stability of his own character.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:17
verses.text: For that is: "To keep silence even from good words;" since one who has a good conscience ought not to be troubled by false words, nor ought he to make more of another's abuse than of the witness of his own heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:19
verses.text: So, then, let a man guard also his humility.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:20
verses.text: If, however, he is unwilling to appear too humble, he thinks as follows, and says within himself: "Am I to allow this man to despise me, and say such things to my face against me, as though I could not open my mouth before him? Why should I not also say something whereby I can grieve him? Am I to let him do me wrong, as though I were not a man, and as though I could not avenge myself? Is he to bring charges against me as though I could not bring together worse ones against him?"  20.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:21
verses.text: Whoever speaks like this is not gentle and humble, nor is he without temptation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:22
verses.text: The tempter stirs him up, and himself puts such thoughts in his heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:23
verses.text: Often and often, too, the evil spirit employs another person, and gets him to say such things to him; but do thou set thy foot firm on the rock.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:24
verses.text: Although a slave should abuse, let the just man be silent, and if a weak man utter insults, let him be silent, and if a poor man should make accusations, let him not answer.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 5:25
verses.text: These are the weapons of the just man, so that he may conquer by giving way, as those skilled in throwing the javelin are wont to conquer by giving way, and in flight to wound their pursuers with severer blows.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:2
verses.text: In this matter we must imitate David's silence and humility, so as not even to seem deserving of harm.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:4
verses.text: What need is there to be troubled when we hear abuse? Why do we not imitate him who says: "I was dumb and humbled myself, and kept silence even from good words"? Or did David only say this, and not act up to it? No, he also acted up to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:5
verses.text: For when Shimei the son of Gera reviled him, David was silent; and although he was surrounded with armed men he did not return the abuse, nor sought revenge: nay, even when the son of Zeruiah spoke to him, because he wished to take vengeance on him, David did not permit it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:6
verses.text: He went on as though dumb, and humbled; he went on in silence; nor was he disturbed, although called a bloody man, for he was conscious of his own gentleness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:7
verses.text: He therefore was not disturbed by insults, for he had full knowledge of his own good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:9
verses.text: He, then, who is quickly roused by wrong makes himself seem deserving of insult, even whilst he wishes to be shown not to deserve it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:10
verses.text: He who despises wrongs is better off than he who grieves over them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 6:11
verses.text: For he who despises them looks down on them, as though he feels them not; but he who grieves over them is tormented, just as though he actually felt them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:4
verses.text: [xxxviii.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:5
verses.text: ] takes the place of an introduction.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:6
verses.text: Incited thereto by this psalm the saint determines to write on duties.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:7
verses.text: He does this with more reason even than Cicero, who wrote on this subject to his son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:8
verses.text: How, further, this is so.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:10
verses.text: Not without thought did I make use of the beginning of this psalm, in writing to you, my children.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:11
verses.text: For this psalm which the Prophet David gave to Jeduthun to sing, I urge you to regard, being delighted myself with its depth of meaning and the excellency of its maxims.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:12
verses.text: For we have learnt in those words we have just shortly touched upon, that both patience in keeping silence and the duty of awaiting a fit time for speaking are taught in this psalm, as well as contempt of riches in the following verses, which things are the chief groundwork of virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:13
verses.text: Whilst, therefore, meditating on this psalm, it has come to my mind to write "on the Duties".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:15
verses.text: Although some philosophers have written on this subject,—Panaetius, for instance, and his son amongst the Greek, Cicero amongst the Latin, writers—I did not think it foreign to my office to write also myself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:16
verses.text: And as Cicero wrote for the instruction of his son, so I, too, write to teach you, my children.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:17
verses.text: For I love you, whom I have begotten in the Gospel, no less than if you were my own true sons.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:18
verses.text: For nature does not make us love more ardently than grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:19
verses.text: We certainly ought to love those who we think will be with us for evermore than those who will be with us in this world only.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:20
verses.text: These often are born unworthy of their race, so as to bring disgrace on their father; but you we chose beforehand, to love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:21
verses.text: They are loved naturally, of necessity, which is not a sufficiently suitable and constant teacher to implant a lasting love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 7:22
verses.text: But ye are loved on the ground of our deliberate choice, whereby a great feeling of affection is combined with the strength of our love: thus one tests what one loves and loves what one has chosen.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:2
verses.text: The word "Duty" has been often used both by philosophers and in the holy Scriptures; from whence it is derived.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:4
verses.text: Since, therefore, the person concerned is one fit to write on the Duties, let us see whether the subject itself stands on the same ground, and whether this word is suitable only to the schools of the philosophers, or is also to be found in the sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:5
verses.text: Beautifully has the Holy Spirit, as it happens, brought before us a passage in reading the Gospel to-day, as though He would urge us to write; whereby we are confirmed in our view, that the word officium, "duty," may also be used with us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:6
verses.text: For when Zacharias the priest was struck dumb in the temple, and could not speak, it is said: "And it came to pass that as soon as the days of his duty [officii] were accomplished, he departed to his own house".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:7
verses.text: We read, therefore, that the word officium, "duty," can be used by us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 8:9
verses.text: And this is not inconsistent with reason, since we consider that the word officium (duty) is derived from efficere (to effect), and is formed with the change of one letter for the sake of euphony; or at any rate that you should do those things which injure [officiant] no one, but benefit all.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:2
verses.text: A duty is to be chosen from what is virtuous, and from what is useful, and also from the comparison of the two, one with the other; but nothing is recognized by Christians as virtuous or useful which is not helpful to the future life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:3
verses.text: This treatise on duty, therefore, will not be superfluous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:5
verses.text: The philosophers considered that duties were derived from what is virtuous and what is useful, and that from these two one should choose the better.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:6
verses.text: Then, they say, it may happen that two virtuous or two useful things will clash together, and the question is, which is the more virtuous, and which the more useful? First, therefore, "duty" is divided into three sections: what is virtuous, what is useful, and what is the better of two.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:7
verses.text: Then, again, these three are divided into five classes; that is, two that are virtuous, two that are useful, and, lastly, the right judgment as to the choice between them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:8
verses.text: The first they say has to do with the moral dignity and integrity of life; the second with the conveniences of life, with wealth, resources, opportunities; whilst a right judgment must underlie the choice of any of them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:9
verses.text: This is what the philosophers say.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:11
verses.text: But we measure nothing at all but that which is fitting and virtuous, and that by the rule of things future rather than of things present; and we state nothing to be useful but what will help us to the blessing of eternal life; certainly not that which will help us enjoy merely the present time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:12
verses.text: Nor do we recognize any advantages in opportunities and in the wealth of earthly goods, but consider them as disadvantages if not put aside, and to be looked on as a burden, when we have them, rather than as a loss when expended.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:14
verses.text: This work of ours, therefore, is not superfluous, seeing that we and they regard duty in quite different ways.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:15
verses.text: They reckon the advantages of this life among the good things, we reckon them among the evil things; for he who receives good things here, as the rich man in the parable, is tormented there; and Lazarus, who endured evil things here, there found comfort.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 9:16
verses.text: Lastly, those who do not read their writings may read ours if they will—if, that is, they do not require great adornment of language or a skilfully-treated subject, but are satisfied with the simple charm of the subject itself.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:2
verses.text: What is seemly is often found in the sacred writings long before it appears in the books of the philosophers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:3
verses.text: Pythagoras borrowed the law of his silence from David.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:4
verses.text: David's rule, however, is the best, for our first duty is to have due measure in speaking.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:6
verses.text: We are instructed and taught that "what is seemly" is put in our Scriptures in the first place.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:7
verses.text: (In Greek it is called πρέπον.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:8
verses.text: ) For we read: "A Hymn beseems Thee, O God, in Sion".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:9
verses.text: In Greek this is: Σοί πρέπει ὕμνος ὁ θεὸς ἐν Σιών.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:10
verses.text: And the Apostle says: "Speak the things which become sound doctrine".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:11
verses.text: And elsewhere: "For it beseemed Him through Whom are all things and for Whom are all things, in bringing many sons unto glory, to make the Captain of their salvation perfect through sufferings".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:13
verses.text: Was Panaetius or Aristotle, who also wrote on duty, earlier than David? Why, Pythagoras himself, who lived before the time of Socrates, followed the prophet David's steps and gave his disciples a law of silence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:14
verses.text: He went so far as to restrain his disciples from the use of speech for five years.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:15
verses.text: David, on the other hand, gave his law, not with a view to impair the gift of nature, but to teach us to take heed to the words we utter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:16
verses.text: Pythagoras again made his rule, that he might teach men to speak by not speaking.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:17
verses.text: But David made his, so that by speaking we might learn the more how to speak.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:18
verses.text: How can there be instruction without exercise, or advance without practice?  32.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:19
verses.text: A man wishing to undergo a warlike training daily exercises himself with his weapons.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:20
verses.text: As though ready for action he rehearses his part in the fight and stands forth just as if the enemy were in position before him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:21
verses.text: Or, with a view to acquiring skill and strength in throwing the javelin, he either puts his own arms to the proof, or avoids the blows of his foes, and escapes them by his watchful attention.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:22
verses.text: The man that desires to navigate a ship on the sea, or to row, tries first on a river.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:23
verses.text: They who wish to acquire an agreeable style of singing and a beautiful voice begin by bringing out their voice gradually by singing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:24
verses.text: And they who seek to win the crown of victory by strength of body and in a regular wrestling match, harden their limbs by daily practice in the wrestling school, foster their endurance, and accustom themselves to hard work.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:26
verses.text: Nature herself teaches us this in the case of infants.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:27
verses.text: For they first exercise themselves in the sounds of speech and so learn to speak.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:28
verses.text: Thus these sounds of speech are a kind of practice, and a school for the voice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:29
verses.text: Let those then who want to learn to take heed in speaking not refuse what is according to nature, but let them use all watchful care; just as those who are on a watch-tower keep on the alert by watching, and not by going to sleep.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:30
verses.text: For everything is made more perfect and strong by exercises proper and suitable to itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:32
verses.text: David, therefore, was not always silent, but only for a time; not perpetually nor to all did he refuse to speak; but he used not to answer the enemy that provoked him, the sinner that exasperated him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:33
verses.text: As he says elsewhere: "As though he were deaf he heard not them that speak vanity and imagine deceit: and as though he were dumb he opened not his mouth to them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:34
verses.text: Again, in another place, it is said: "Answer  not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like to him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:35
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:36
verses.text: The first duty then is to have due measure in our speech.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:37
verses.text: In this way a sacrifice of praise is offered up to God; thus a godly fear is shown when the sacred Scriptures are read; thus parents are honoured.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:38
verses.text: I know well that many speak because they know not how to keep silence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:39
verses.text: But it is not often any one is silent when speaking does not profit him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:40
verses.text: A wise man, intending to speak, first carefully considers what he is to say, and to whom he is to say it; also where and at what time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:41
verses.text: There is therefore such a thing as due measure in keeping silence and also in speaking; there is also such a thing as a due measure in what we do.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 10:42
verses.text: It is a glorious thing to maintain the right standard of duty.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:2
verses.text: It is proved by the witness of Scripture that all duty is either "ordinary" or "perfect".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:3
verses.text: To which is added a word in praise of mercy, and an exhortation to practise it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:5
verses.text: Every duty is either "ordinary" or "perfect," a fact which we can also confirm by the authority of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:6
verses.text: For we read in the Gospel that the Lord said: "If thou wilt enter into life, keep the commandments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:7
verses.text: He saith: Which? Jesus said to him: Thou shalt do no murder, Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witness, Honour thy father and thy mother, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:8
verses.text: These are ordinary duties, to which something is wanting.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:10
verses.text: Upon this the young man says to Him: "All these things have I kept from my youth up, what lack I yet? Jesus said unto him: If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell all thy goods and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven; and come and follow Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:11
verses.text: And earlier the same is written, where the Lord says that we must love our enemies, and pray for those that falsely accuse and persecute us, and bless those that curse us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:12
verses.text: This we are bound to do, if we would be perfect as our Father Who is in heaven; Who bids the sun to shed his rays over the evil and the good, and makes the lands of the whole universe fertile with rain and dew without any distinction.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:13
verses.text: This, then, is a perfect duty (the Greeks call it κατόρθωμα), whereby all things are put right which could have any failings in them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:15
verses.text: Mercy, also, is a good thing, for it makes men perfect, in that it imitates the perfect Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:16
verses.text: Nothing graces the Christian soul so much as mercy; mercy as shown chiefly towards the poor, that thou mayest treat them as sharers in common with thee in the produce of nature, which brings forth the fruits of the earth for use to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:17
verses.text: Thus thou mayest freely give to a poor man what thou hast, and in this way help him who is thy brother and companion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:18
verses.text: Thou bestowest silver; he receives life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:19
verses.text: Thou givest money; he considers it his fortune.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:20
verses.text: Thy coin makes up all his property.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:22
verses.text: Further, he bestows more on thee than thou on him, since he is thy debtor in regard to thy salvation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:23
verses.text: If thou clothe the naked, thou clothest thyself with righteousness; if thou bring the stranger under thy roof, if thou support the needy, he procures for thee the friendship of the saints and eternal habitations.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:24
verses.text: That is no small recompense.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:25
verses.text: Thou sowest earthly things and receivest heavenly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:26
verses.text: Dost thou wonder at the judgment of God in the case of holy Job? Wonder rather at his virtue, in that he could say: "I was an eye to the blind, and a foot to the lame.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:27
verses.text: I was a father to the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:28
verses.text: Their shoulders were made warm with the skins of my lambs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:29
verses.text: The stranger dwelt not at my gates, but my door was open to every one that came".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:30
verses.text: Clearly blessed is he from whose house a poor man has never gone with empty hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:31
verses.text: Nor again is any one more blessed than he who is sensible of the needs of the poor, and the hardships of the weak and helpless.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 11:32
verses.text: In the day of judgment he will receive salvation from the Lord, Whom he will have as his debtor for the mercy he has shown.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:2
verses.text: To prevent any one from being checked in the exercise of mercy, he shows that God cares for human actions; and proves on the evidence of Job that all wicked men are unhappy in the very abundance of their wealth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:4
verses.text: But many are kept back from the duty of showing active mercy, because they suppose that God does not care about the actions of men, or that He does not know what we do in secret, and what our conscience has in view.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:5
verses.text: Some again think that His judgment  in no wise seems to be just; for they see that sinners have abundance of riches, that they enjoy honours, health, and children; while, on the other hand, the just live in poverty and unhonoured, they are without children, sickly in body, and often in grief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:7
verses.text: That is no small point.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:8
verses.text: For those three royal friends of Job declared him to be a sinner, because they saw that he, after being rich, became poor; that after having many children, he had lost them all, and that he was now covered with sores and was full of weals, and was a mass of wounds from head to foot.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:9
verses.text: But holy Job made this declaration to them: "If I suffer thus because of my sins, why do the wicked live? They grow old also in riches, their seed is according to their pleasure, their children are before their eyes, their houses are prosperous; but they have no fear; there is no scourge from the Lord on them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:11
verses.text: A faint-hearted man, seeing this, is disturbed in mind, and turns his attention away from it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:12
verses.text: Holy Job, when about to speak in the words of such a one, began thus, saying: "Bear with me, I also will speak; then laugh at me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:13
verses.text: For if I am found fault with, I am found fault with as a man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:14
verses.text: Bear, therefore, the burden of my words".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:15
verses.text: For I am going to say (he means) what I do not approve; but I shall utter wrong words to refute you.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:16
verses.text: Or, to translate it in another way: "How now? Am I found fault with by a man?" That is: a man cannot find fault with me because I have sinned, although I deserve to be found fault with; for ye do not find fault with me on the ground of an open sin, but estimate what I deserve for my offences by the extent of my misfortunes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:17
verses.text: Thus the faint-hearted man, seeing that the wicked succeed and prosper, whilst he himself is crushed by misfortune, says to the Lord: "Depart from me, I desire not the knowledge of Thy ways.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:18
verses.text: What good is it that we serve Him, or what use to hasten to Him? In the hands of the wicked are all good things, but He sees not their works".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:20
verses.text: Plato has been greatly praised, because in his book "on the State," he has made the person who undertook the part of objector against justice to ask pardon for his words, of which he himself did not approve; and to say that that character was only assumed for the sake of finding out the truth and to investigate the question at issue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:21
verses.text: And Cicero so far approved of this, that he also, in his book which he wrote "on the Commonwealth," thought something must be said against that idea.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:23
verses.text: How many years before these did Job live! He was the first to discover this, and to consider what excuses had to be made for this, not for the sake of decking out his eloquence, but for the sake of finding out the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:24
verses.text: At once he made the matter plain, stating that the lamp of the wicked is put out, that their destruction will come; that God, the teacher of wisdom and instruction, is not deceived, but is a judge of the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:25
verses.text: Therefore the blessedness of individuals must not be estimated at the value of their known wealth, but according to the voice of their conscience within them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:26
verses.text: For this, as a true and uncorrupted judge of punishments and rewards, decides between the deserts of the innocent and the guilty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:27
verses.text: The innocent man dies in the strength of his own simplicity, in the full possession of his own will; having a soul filled as it were with marrow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:28
verses.text: But the sinner, though he has abundance in life, and lives in the midst of luxury, and is redolent with sweet scents, ends his life in the bitterness of his soul, and brings his last day to a close, taking with him none of those good things which he once enjoyed—carrying away nothing with him but the price of his own wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:29
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:30
verses.text: In thinking of this, deny if thou canst that a recompense is paid by divine judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:31
verses.text: The former feels happy in his heart, the latter wretched; that man on his own verdict is guiltless, this one a criminal; that man again is happy in leaving the world, this man grieves over it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:32
verses.text: Who can be pronounced guiltless that is not innocent in the sight of his own conscience? "Tell me," he says, "where is the covering of his tabernacle; his token will not be found".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:33
verses.text: The life of the criminal is as a dream.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:34
verses.text: He has opened his eyes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:35
verses.text: His repose has departed, his enjoyment has fled.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:36
verses.text: Nay, that very repose of the wicked, which even while they live is only seeming, is now in hell, for alive they go down into hell.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:37
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:38
verses.text: Thou seest the enjoyments of the sinner; but question his conscience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:39
verses.text: Will he not be more foul than any sepulchre? Thou beholdest his joy, thou admirest the bodily health of his children, and the amount of his wealth; but look within at the sores and wounds of his soul, the sadness of his heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:40
verses.text: And what shall I say of his wealth, when  thou readest: "For a man's life consisteth not in the abundance of the things which he possesseth"? When thou knowest, that though he seems to thee to be rich, to himself he is poor, and in his own person refutes thy judgment? What also shall I say of the number of his children and of his freedom from pain—when he is full of grief and decides that he will have no heir, and does not wish that those who copy his ways should succeed him? For the sinner really leaves no heir.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 12:41
verses.text: Thus the wicked man is a punishment to himself, but the upright man is a grace to himself—and to either, whether good or bad, the reward of his deeds is paid in his own person.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:2
verses.text: The ideas of those philosophers are refuted who deny to God the care of the whole world, or of any of its parts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:4
verses.text: But let us return to our point, lest we seem to have lost sight of the break we made in answering the ideas of those who, seeing some wicked men, rich, joyous, full of honours, and powerful, whilst many upright men are in want and are weak,—suppose therefore that God either cares nothing about us (which is what the Epicureans say), or that He is ignorant of men's actions as the wicked say—or that, if He knows all things, He is an unjust judge in allowing the good to be in want and the wicked to have abundance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:5
verses.text: But it did not seem out of place to make a digression to meet an idea of this kind and to contrast it with the feelings of those very persons whom they consider happy—for they think themselves wretched.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:6
verses.text: I suppose they would believe themselves more readily than us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:8
verses.text: After this digression I consider it an easy matter to refute the rest—above all the declaration of those who think that God has no care whatever for the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:9
verses.text: For instance, Aristotle declares that His providence extends only to the moon.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:10
verses.text: But what workman is there who gives no care to his work? Who would forsake and abandon what he believes himself to have produced? If it is derogatory to rule, is it not more so to have created? Though there is no wrong involved in not creating anything, it is surely the height of cruelty not to care for what one has created.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:12
verses.text: But if some deny God to be the Creator, and so count themselves amongst the beasts and irrational creatures, what shall we say of those who condemn themselves to such indignity? They themselves declare that God pervades all things, that all depend upon His power, that His might and majesty penetrate all the elements,—lands, heaven, and seas; yet they think it derogatory to Him to enter into man's spirit, which is the noblest thing He has given us, and to be there with the full knowledge of the divine Majesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:14
verses.text: But philosophers who are held to be reasonable laugh at the teacher of these ideas as besotted and licentious.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:15
verses.text: But what shall I say of Aristotle's idea? He thinks that God is satisfied with His own narrow bounds, and lives within the prescribed limits of His kingdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:16
verses.text: This, however, is also what the poets' tales tell us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:17
verses.text: For they relate that the world is divided between three gods, so that it has fallen to the lot of one to restrain and rule heaven, to another the sea, and to a third the lower regions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:18
verses.text: They have also to take care not to stir up war one with the other by allowing thoughts and cares about the belongings of others to take hold of them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:19
verses.text: In the same way, Aristotle also declares that God has no care for the earth, as He has none for the sea or the lower regions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 13:20
verses.text: How is it that these philosophers shut out of their ranks the poets whose footsteps they follow?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:2
verses.text: Nothing escapes God's knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:3
verses.text: This is proved by the witness of the Scriptures and the analogy of the sun, which, although created, yet by its light or heat enters into all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:5
verses.text: Next comes the answer to the question, whether God, not having failed to show care for His work, now fails to have knowledge of it? Thus it is written: "He that planted the ear, shall He not hear? He that made the eye, shall He not regard?"  52.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:6
verses.text: This false idea was not unknown to the holy prophets.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:7
verses.text: David himself introduces men to speak whom pride has filled and claimed for its own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:8
verses.text: For what shows greater pride than when men who are living in sin think it unfit that other sinners should live, and say: "Lord, how long shall the ungodly, how long shall the ungodly  triumph?" And later on: "And yet they say, the Lord shall not see: neither shall the God of Jacob regard it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:9
verses.text: Whom the prophet answers, saying: "Take heed, ye unwise among the people: O ye fools, when will ye understand? He that planted the ear, shall He not hear? or He that made the eye, shall He not see? He that rebuketh the nations, shall He not punish?—He that teacheth man knowledge? The Lord knoweth the thoughts of man that they are vain".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:10
verses.text: Does He Who discerns whatsoever is vain not know what is holy, and is He ignorant of what He Himself has made? Can the workman be ignorant of his own work? This one is a man, yet he discerns what is hidden in his work; and God—shall He not know His own work? Is there more depth, then, in the work than in its author? Has He made something superior to Himself; the value of which, as its Author, He was ignorant of, and whose condition He knew not, though He was its Director? So much for these persons.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:12
verses.text: But we are satisfied with the witness of Him Who says: "I search out the heart and the reins".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:13
verses.text: In the Gospel, also, the Lord Jesus says: "Why think ye evil in your hearts? For He knew they were thinking evil".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:14
verses.text: The evangelist also witnesses to this, saying: "For Jesus knew their thoughts".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:16
verses.text: The idea of these people will not trouble us much if we look at their actions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:17
verses.text: They will not have Him to be judge over them, Whom nothing deceives; they will not grant to Him the knowledge of things hidden, for they are afraid their own hidden things may be brought to light.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:18
verses.text: But the Lord, also, "knowing their works, has given them over unto darkness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:19
verses.text: In the night," he says, "he will be as a thief, and the eye of the adulterer will watch for the darkness, saying, No eye shall see me; he hath covered up his face".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:20
verses.text: For every one that avoids the light loves darkness, seeking to be hid, though he cannot be hid from God, Who knows not only what is transacted, but also what will be thought of, both in the depths of space and in the minds of men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:21
verses.text: Thus, again, he who speaks in the book Ecclesiasticus says: "Who seeth me? The darkness hath covered me, and the walls have hidden me; whom do I fear?" But although lying on his bed he may think thus, he is caught where he never thought of it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:22
verses.text: "It shall be," it says, "a shame to him because he knew not what the fear of the Lord was".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:24
verses.text: But what can be more foolish than to suppose that anything escapes God's notice, when the sun which supplies the light enters even hidden spots, and the strength of its heat reaches to the foundations of a house and its inner chambers? Who can deny that the depths of the earth, which the winter's ice has bound together, are warmed by the mildness of spring? Surely the very heart of a tree feels the force of heat or cold, to such an extent that its roots are either nipped with the cold or sprout forth in the warmth of the sun.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:25
verses.text: In short, wherever the mildness of heaven smiles on the earth, there the earth produces in abundance fruits of different kinds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 14:27
verses.text: If, then, the sun's rays pour their light over all the earth and enter into its hidden spots; if they cannot be checked by iron bars or the barrier of heavy doors from getting within, how can it be impossible for the Glory of God, which is instinct with life, to enter into the thoughts and hearts of men that He Himself has created? And how shall it not see what He Himself has created? Did He make His works to be better and more powerful than He Himself is, Who made them (in this event) so as to escape the notice of their Creator whensoever they will? Did He implant such perfection and power in our mind that He Himself could not comprehend it when He wished?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:2
verses.text: Those who are dissatisfied with the fact that the good receive evil, and the evil good, are shown by the example of Lazarus, and on the authority of Paul, that punishments and rewards are reserved for a future life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:4
verses.text: We have fully discussed two questions; and this discussion, as we think, has not turned out quite unfavourably for us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:5
verses.text: A third question yet remains; it is this: Why do sinners have abundance of wealth and riches, and fare sumptuously, and have no grief or sorrow; whilst the upright are in want, and are punished by the loss of wives or children? Now, that parable in the Gospel ought to satisfy persons like these; for the rich man was clothed in purple and fine linen, and dined sumptuously every day; but the beggar, full of sores, used to gather the crumbs of his table.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:6
verses.text: After the death of  the two, however, the beggar was in Abraham's bosom in rest; the rich man was in torment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:7
verses.text: Is it not plain from this that rewards and punishments according to deserts await one after death?  58.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:8
verses.text: And surely this is but right.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:9
verses.text: For in a contest there is much labour needed—and after the contest victory falls to some, to others disgrace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:10
verses.text: Is the palm ever given or the crown granted before the course is finished? Paul writes well; He says: "I have fought a good fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith; henceforth there is laid up for me a crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous judge, shall give me at that day; and not to me only, but unto all them also that love His appearing".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:11
verses.text: "In that day," he says, He will give it—not here.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:12
verses.text: Here he fought, in labours, in dangers, in shipwrecks, like a good wrestler; for he knew how that "through much tribulation we must enter into the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 15:13
verses.text: Therefore no one can receive a reward, unless he has striven lawfully; nor is the victory a glorious one, unless the contest also has been toilsome.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:2
verses.text: To confirm what has been said above about rewards and punishments, he adds that it is not strange if there is no reward reserved for some in the future; for they do not labour here nor struggle.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:3
verses.text: He goes on to say also that for this reason temporal goods are granted to these persons, so that they may have no excuse whatever.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:5
verses.text: Is not he unjust who gives the reward before the end of the contest? Therefore the Lord says in the Gospel: "Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:6
verses.text: He said not: "Blessed are the rich," but "the poor".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:7
verses.text: By the divine judgment blessedness begins there whence human misery is supposed to spring.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:8
verses.text: "Blessed are they that hunger, for they shall be filled; Blessed are they that mourn, for they shall be comforted; Blessed are the merciful, for God will have mercy on them; Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God; Blessed are they that are persecuted for righteousness' sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven; Blessed are ye when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you for righteousness' sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:9
verses.text: Rejoice and be exceeding glad, for plentiful is your reward in heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:10
verses.text: A reward future and not present,—in heaven, not on earth,—has He promised shall be given.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:11
verses.text: What further dost thou expect? What further is due? Why dost thou demand the crown with so much haste, before thou dost conquer? Why dost thou desire to shake off the dust and to rest? Why dost thou long to sit at the feast before the course is finished? As yet the people are looking on, the athletes are in the arena, and thou—dost thou already look for ease?  60.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:12
verses.text: Perhaps thou sayest: Why are the wicked joyous? why do they live in luxury? why do they not toil with me? It is because they who have not put down their names to strive for the crown are not bound to undergo the labours of the contest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:13
verses.text: They who have not gone down into the race-course do not anoint themselves with oil nor get covered with dust.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:14
verses.text: For those whom glory awaits trouble is at hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:15
verses.text: The perfumed spectators are wont to look on, not to join in the struggle, nor to endure the sun, the heat, the dust, and the showers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:16
verses.text: Let the athletes say to them: Come, strive with us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:17
verses.text: The spectators will but answer: We sit here now to decide about you, but you, if you conquer, will gain the glory of the crown and we shall not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:19
verses.text: They, then, who have devoted themselves to pleasures, luxury, robbery, gain, or honours are spectators rather than combatants.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:20
verses.text: They have the profit of labour, but not the fruits of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:21
verses.text: They love their ease; by cunning and wickedness they heap up riches; but they will pay the penalty of their iniquity, though it be late.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:22
verses.text: Their rest will be in hell, thine in heaven; their home in the grave, thine in paradise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:23
verses.text: Whence Job said beautifully that they watch in the tomb, for they cannot have the calm of quiet rest which he enjoys who shall rise again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:24
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:25
verses.text: Do not, therefore, understand, or speak, or think as a child; nor as a child claim those things now which belong to a future time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:26
verses.text: The crown belongs to the perfect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:27
verses.text: Wait till that which is perfect is come, when thou mayest know—not through a glass as in a riddle, but face to face—the very form of truth made clear.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:28
verses.text: Then will be made known why that person was rich who was wicked and a robber of other men's goods, why another was powerful, why a third had many children, and yet a fourth was loaded with honours.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:29
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:30
verses.text: Perhaps all this happens that the question may be asked of the robber: Thou  wast rich, wherefore didst thou seize on the goods of others? Need did not force thee, poverty did not drive thee to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:31
verses.text: Did I not make thee rich, that thou mightest have no excuse? So, too, it may be said to a person of power: Why didst thou not aid the widow, the orphans also, when enduring wrong? Wast thou powerless? Couldst thou not help? I made thee for this purpose, not that thou mightest do wrong, but that thou mightest check it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:32
verses.text: Is it not written for thee "Save him that endureth wrong?" Is it not written for thee: "Deliver the poor and needy out of the hand of the sinner"? It may be said also to the man who has abundance of good things: I have blessed thee with children and honours; I have granted thee health of body; why didst thou not follow my commands? My servant, what have I done to thee, or how have I grieved thee? Was it not I that gave thee children, bestowed honours, granted health to thee? Why didst thou deny me? Why didst thou suppose that thy actions would not come to my knowledge? Why didst thou accept my gifts, yet despise my commands?  64.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:33
verses.text: We can gather the same from the example of the traitor Judas.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:34
verses.text: He was chosen among the Twelve Apostles, and had charge of the money bag, to lay it out upon the poor, that it might not seem as though he had betrayed the Lord because he was unhonoured or in want.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 16:35
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord granted him this office, that He might also be justified in him; he would be guilty of a greater fault, not as one driven to it by wrong done to him, but as one misusing grace.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:2
verses.text: The duties of youth, and examples suitable to that age, are next put forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:4
verses.text: Since it has been made sufficiently plain that there will be punishment for wickedness and reward for virtue, let us proceed to speak of the duties which have to be borne in mind from our youth up, that they may grow with our years.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:5
verses.text: A good youth ought to have a fear of God, to be subject to his parents, to give honour to his elders, to preserve his purity; he ought not to despise humility, but should love forbearance and modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:6
verses.text: All these are an ornament to youthful years.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:7
verses.text: For as seriousness is the true grace of an old man, and ardour of a young man, so also is modesty, as though by some gift of nature, well set off in a youth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:9
