verses.text: Isaac feared the Lord, as was indeed but natural in the son of Abraham; being subject also to his father to such an extent that he would not avoid death in opposition to his father's will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:10
verses.text: Joseph also, though he dreamed that sun and moon and stars made obeisance to him, yet was subject to his father's will with ready obedience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:11
verses.text: So chaste was he, he would not hear even a word unless it were pure; humble was he even to doing the work of a slave, modest, even to taking flight, enduring, even to bearing imprisonment, so forgiving of wrong as even to repay it with good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:12
verses.text: Whose modesty was such, that, when seized by a woman, he preferred to leave his garment in her hands in flight, rather than to lay aside his modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 17:13
verses.text: Moses, also, and Jeremiah, chosen by the Lord to declare the words of God to the people, were for avoiding, through modesty, that which through grace they could do.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:2
verses.text: On the different functions of modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:3
verses.text: How it should qualify both speech and silence, accompany chastity, commend our prayers to God, govern our bodily motions; on which last point reference is made to two clerics in language by no means unsuited to its object.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:4
verses.text: Further he proceeds to say that one's gait should be in accordance with that same virtue, and how careful one must be that nothing immodest come forth from one's mouth, or be noticed in one's body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:5
verses.text: All these points are illustrated with very appropriate examples.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:7
verses.text: Lovely, then, is the virtue of modesty, and sweet is its grace! It is seen not only in actions, but even in our words, so that we may not go beyond due measure in speech, and that our words may not have an unbecoming sound.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:8
verses.text: The mirror of our mind often enough reflects its image in our words.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:9
verses.text: Sobriety weighs out the sound even of our voice, for fear that too loud a voice should offend the ear of any one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:10
verses.text: Nay, in singing itself the first rule is modesty, and the same is true in every kind of speech, too, so that a man may gradually learn to praise God, or to sing songs, or even to speak, in that the principles of modesty grace his advance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:12
verses.text: Silence, again, wherein all the other  virtues rest, is the chief act of modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:13
verses.text: Only, if it is supposed to be a sign of a childish or proud spirit, it is accounted a reproach; if a sign of modesty, it is reckoned for praise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:14
verses.text: Susanna was silent in danger, and thought the loss of modesty was worse than loss of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:15
verses.text: She did not consider that her safety should be guarded at the risk of her chastity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:16
verses.text: To God alone she spoke, to Whom she could speak out in true modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:17
verses.text: She avoided looking on the face of men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:18
verses.text: For there is also modesty in the glance of the eye, which makes a woman unwilling to look upon men, or to be seen by them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:20
verses.text: Let no one suppose that this praise belongs to chastity alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:21
verses.text: For modesty is the companion of purity, in company with which chastity itself is safer.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:22
verses.text: Shame, again, is good as a companion and guide of chastity, inasmuch as it does not suffer purity to be defiled in approaching even the outskirts of danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:23
verses.text: This it is that, at the very outset of her recognition, commends the Mother of the Lord to those who read the Scriptures, and, as a credible witness, declares her worthy to be chosen to such an office.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:24
verses.text: For when in her chamber, alone, she is saluted by the angel, she is silent, and is disturbed at his entrance, and the Virgin's face is troubled at the strange appearance of a man's form.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:25
verses.text: And so, though she was humble, yet it was not because of this, but on account of her modesty, that she did not return his salutation, nor give him any answer, except to ask, when she had learnt that she should conceive the Lord, how this should be.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:26
verses.text: She certainly did not speak merely for the sake of making a reply.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:28
verses.text: In our very prayers, too, modesty is most pleasing, and gains us much grace from our God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:29
verses.text: Was it not this that exalted the publican, and commended him, when he dared not raise even his eyes to heaven? So he was justified by the judgment of the Lord rather than the Pharisee, whom overweening pride made so hideous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:30
verses.text: "Therefore let us pray in the incorruptibility of a meek and quiet spirit, which is in the sight of God of great price," as St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:31
verses.text: Peter says.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:32
verses.text: A noble thing, then, is modesty, which, though giving up its rights, seizing on nothing for itself, laying claim to nothing, and in some ways somewhat retiring within the sphere of its own powers, yet is rich in the sight of God, in Whose sight no man is rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:33
verses.text: Rich is modesty, for it is the portion of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:34
verses.text: Paul also bids that prayer be offered up with modesty and sobriety.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:35
verses.text: He desires that this should be first, and, as it were, lead the way of prayers to come, so that the sinner's prayer may not be boastful, but veiled, as it were, with the blush of shame, may merit a far greater degree of grace, in giving way to modesty at the remembrance of its fault.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:36
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:37
verses.text: Modesty must further be guarded in our very movements and gestures and gait.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:38
verses.text: For the condition of the mind is often seen in the attitude of the body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:39
verses.text: For this reason the hidden man of our heart (our inner self) is considered to be either frivolous, boastful, or boisterous, or, on the other hand, steady, firm, pure, and dependable.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:40
verses.text: Thus the movement of the body is a sort of voice of the soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:41
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:42
verses.text: Ye remember, my children, that a friend of ours who seemed to recommend himself by his assiduity in his duties, yet was not admitted by me into the number of the clergy, because his gestures were too unseemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:43
verses.text: Also that I bade one, whom I found already among the clergy, never to go in front of me, because he actually pained me by the seeming arrogance of his gait.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:44
verses.text: That is what I said when he returned to his duty after an offence committed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:45
verses.text: This alone I would not allow, nor did my mind deceive me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:46
verses.text: For both have left the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:47
verses.text: What their gait betrayed them to be, such were they proved to be by the faithlessness of their hearts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:48
verses.text: The one forsook his faith at the time of the Arian troubles; the other, through love of money, denied that he belonged to us, so that he might not have to undergo sentence at the hands of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:49
verses.text: In their gait was discernible the semblance of fickleness, the appearance, as it were, of wandering buffoons.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:50
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:51
verses.text: Some there are who in walking perceptibly copy the gestures of actors, and act as though they were bearers in the processions, and had the motions of nodding statues, to such an extent that they seem to keep a sort of time, as often as they change their step.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:52
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:53
verses.text: Nor do I think it becoming to walk hurriedly, except when a case of some danger demands it, or a real necessity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:54
verses.text: For we often see those who hurry come up panting, and with features distorted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:55
verses.text: But if there is no reason for the need of such hurry, it gives cause for just offence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:56
verses.text: I am not, however,  talking of those who have to hurry now and then for some particular reason, but of those to whom, by the yoke of constant habit, it has become a second nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:57
verses.text: In the case of the former I cannot approve of their slow solemn movements, which remind one of the forms of phantoms.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:58
verses.text: Nor do I care for the others with their headlong speed, for they put one in mind of the ruin of outcasts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:59
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:60
verses.text: A suitable gait is that wherein there is an appearance of authority and weight and dignity, and which has a calm collected bearing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:61
verses.text: But it must be of such a character that all effort and conceit may be wanting, and that it be simple and plain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:62
verses.text: Nothing counterfeit is pleasing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:63
verses.text: Let nature train our movements.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:64
verses.text: If indeed there is any fault in our nature, let us mend it with diligence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:65
verses.text: And, that artifice may be wanting, let not amendment be wanting.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:66
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:67
verses.text: But if we pay so much attention to things like these, how much more careful ought we to be to let nothing shameful proceed out of our mouth, for that defiles a man terribly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:68
verses.text: It is not food that defiles, but unjust disparagement of others and foul words.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:69
verses.text: These things are openly shameful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:70
verses.text: In our office indeed must no word be let fall at all unseemly, nor one that may give offence to modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:71
verses.text: But not only ought we to say nothing unbecoming to ourselves, but we ought not even to lend our ears to words of this sort.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:72
verses.text: Thus Joseph fled and left his garment, that he might hear nothing inconsistent with his modesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:73
verses.text: For he who delights to listen, urges the other on to speak.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:74
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:75
verses.text: To have full knowledge of what is foul is in the highest degree shameful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:76
verses.text: To see anything of this sort, if by chance it should happen, how dreadful that is! What, therefore, is displeasing to us in others, can that be pleasing in ourselves? Is not nature herself our teacher, who has formed to perfection every part of our body, so as to provide for what is necessary and to beautify and grace its form? However she has left plain and open to the sight those parts which are beautiful to look upon; among which, the head, set as it were above all, and the pleasant lines of the figure, and the appearance of the face are prominent, whilst their usefulness for work is ready to hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:77
verses.text: But those parts in which there is a compliance with the necessities of nature, she has partly put away and hidden in the body itself, lest they should present a disgusting appearance, and partly, too, she has taught and persuaded us to cover them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:78
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:79
verses.text: Is not nature herself then a teacher of modesty? Following her example, the modesty of men, which I suppose is so called from the mode of knowing what is seemly, has covered and veiled what it has found hid in the frame of our body; like that door which Noah was bidden to make in the side of the ark; wherein we find a figure of the Church, and also of the human body, for through that door the remnants of food were cast out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:80
verses.text: Thus the Maker of our nature so thought of our modesty, and so guarded what was seemly and virtuous in our body, as to place what is unseemly behind, and to put it out of the sight of our eyes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:81
verses.text: Of this the Apostle says well: "Those members of the body which seem to be more feeble are necessary, and those members of the body which we think to be less honourable, upon these we bestow more abundant honour, and our uncomely parts have more abundant comeliness".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:82
verses.text: Truly, by following the guidance of nature, diligent care has added to the grace of the body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:83
verses.text: In another place I have gone more fully into this subject, and said that not only do we hide those parts which have been given us to hide, but also that we think it unseemly to mention by name their description, and the use of those members.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:84
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:85
verses.text: And if these parts are exposed to view by chance, modesty is violated; but if on purpose, it is reckoned as utter shamelessness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:86
verses.text: Wherefore Ham, Noah's son, brought disgrace upon himself; for he laughed when he saw his father naked, but they who covered their father received the gift of a blessing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:87
verses.text: For which cause, also, it was an ancient custom in Rome, and in many other states as well, that grown-up sons should not bathe with their parents, or sons-in-law with their fathers-in-law, in order that the great duty of reverence for parents should not be weakened.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:88
verses.text: Many, however, cover themselves so far as they can in the baths, so that, where the whole body is bare, that part of it at least may be covered.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:89
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:90
verses.text: The priests, also, under the old law, as we read in Exodus, wore breeches, as it was told Moses by the Lord: "And thou shalt make them linen breeches to cover their shame: from the loins even to the thighs they shall reach, and Aaron and his sons shall wear them, when they enter into the tabernacle of witness, and when they  come unto the altar of the holy place to offer sacrifice, that they lay not sin upon themselves and die".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 18:91
verses.text: Some of us are said still to observe this, but most explain it spiritually, and suppose it was said with a view to guarding modesty and preserving chastity.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:2
verses.text: How should seemliness be represented by a speaker? Does beauty add anything to virtue, and, if so, how much? Lastly, what care should we take that nothing conceited or effeminate be seen in us?  81.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:3
verses.text: It has given me pleasure to dwell somewhat at length on the various functions of modesty; for I speak to you who either can recognize the good that is in it in your own cases, or at least do not know its loss.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:4
verses.text: Fitted as it is for all ages, persons, times, and places, yet it most beseems youthful and childish years.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:6
verses.text: But at every age we must take care that all we do is seemly and becoming, and that the course of our life forms one harmonious and complete whole.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:7
verses.text: Wherefore Cicero thinks that a certain order ought to be observed in what is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:8
verses.text: He says that this lies in beauty, order, and in appointment fitted for action.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:9
verses.text: This, as he says, it is difficult to explain in words, yet it can be quite sufficiently understood.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:11
verses.text: Why Cicero should have introduced beauty, I do not quite understand; though it is true he also speaks in praise of the powers of the body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:12
verses.text: We certainly do not locate virtue in the beauty of the body, though, on the other hand, we do recognize a certain grace, as when modesty is wont to cover the face with a blush of shame, and to make it more pleasing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:13
verses.text: For as a workman is wont to work better the more suitable his materials are, so modesty is more conspicuous in the comeliness of the body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:14
verses.text: Only the comeliness of the body should not be assumed; it should be natural and artless, unstudied rather than elaborated, not heightened by costly and glistening garments, but just clad in ordinary clothing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:15
verses.text: One must see that nothing is wanting that one's credit or necessity demands, whilst nothing must be added for the sake of splendour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:17
verses.text: The voice, too, should not be languid, nor feeble, nor womanish in its tone,—such a tone of voice as many are in the habit of using, under the idea of seeming important.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:18
verses.text: It should preserve a certain quality, and rhythm, and a manly vigour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:19
verses.text: For all to do what is best suited to their character and sex, that is to attain to beauty of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:20
verses.text: This is the best order for movements, this the employment fitted for every action.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:21
verses.text: But as I cannot approve of a soft or weak tone of voice, or an effeminate gesture of the body, so also I cannot approve of what is boorish and rustic.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:22
verses.text: Let us follow nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 19:23
verses.text: The imitation of her provides us with a principle of training, and gives us a pattern of virtue.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:2
verses.text: If we are to preserve our modesty we must avoid fellowship with profligate men, also the banquets of strangers, and intercourse with women; our leisure time at home should be spent in pious and virtuous pursuits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:4
verses.text: Modesty has indeed its rocks—not any that she brings with her, but those, I mean, which she often runs against, as when we associate with profligate men, who, under the form of pleasantry, administer poison to the good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:5
verses.text: And the latter, if they are very constant in their attendance at banquets and games, and often join in jests, enervate that manly gravity of theirs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:6
verses.text: Let us then take heed that, in wishing to relax our minds, we do not destroy all harmony, the blending as it were of all good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:7
verses.text: For habit quickly bends nature in another direction.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:9
verses.text: For this reason I think that what ye wisely do is befitting to the duties of clerics, and especially to those of the priesthood—namely, that ye avoid the banquets of strangers, but so that ye are still hospitable to travellers, and give no occasion for reproach by reason of your great care in the matter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:10
verses.text: Banquets with strangers engross one's attention, and soon produce a love for feasting.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:11
verses.text: Tales, also, of the world and its pleasures often creep in.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:12
verses.text: One cannot shut one's ears; and to forbid them is looked on as a sign of haughtiness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:13
verses.text: One's glass, too, even against one's will, is filled time after time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:14
verses.text: It is better surely to excuse oneself once for all at one's own home, than often at another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:15
verses.text: When one rises sober, at any rate one's presence need not be condemned by the insolence of another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:17
verses.text: There is no need for the younger clergy to go to the houses of widows or virgins, except for the sake of a definite visit, and in that case only with the elder clergy, that is, with the bishop, or, if the matter be somewhat important, with the priests.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:18
verses.text: Why  should we give room to the world to revile? What need is there for those frequent visits to give ground for rumours? What if one of those women should by chance fall? Why shouldst thou undergo the reproach of another's fall? How many even strong men have been led away by their passions? How many are there who have not indeed yielded to sin, but have given ground for suspicion?  88.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:19
verses.text: Why dost thou not spend the time which thou hast free from thy duties in the church in reading? Why dost thou not go back again to see Christ? Why dost thou not address Him, and hear His voice? We address Him when we pray, we hear Him when we read the sacred oracles of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:20
verses.text: What have we to do with strange houses? There is one house which holds all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:21
verses.text: They who need us can come to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:22
verses.text: What have we to do with tales and fables? An office to minister at the altar of Christ is what we have received; no duty to make ourselves agreeable to men has been laid upon us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:24
verses.text: We ought to be humble, gentle, mild, serious, patient.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 20:25
verses.text: We must keep the mean in all things, so that a calm countenance and quiet speech may show that there is no vice in our lives.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:2
verses.text: We must guard against anger, before it arises; if it has already arisen we must check and calm it, and if we cannot do this either, at least we should keep our tongue from abuse, so that our passions may be like boys' quarrels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:3
verses.text: He relates what Archites said, and shows that David led the way in this matter, both in his actions and in his writings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:5
verses.text: Let anger be guarded against.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:6
verses.text: If it cannot, however, be averted, let it be kept within bounds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:7
verses.text: For indignation is a terrible incentive to sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:8
verses.text: It disorders the mind to such an extent as to leave no room for reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:9
verses.text: The first thing, therefore, to aim at, if possible, is to make tranquillity of character our natural disposition by constant practice, by desire for better things, by fixed determination.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:10
verses.text: But since passion is to a large extent implanted in our nature and character, so that it cannot be uprooted and avoided, it must be checked by reason, if, that is, it can be foreseen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:11
verses.text: And if the mind has already been filled with indignation before it could be foreseen or provided against in any way, we must consider how to conquer the passion of the mind, how to restrain our anger, that it may no more be so filled.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:12
verses.text: Resist wrath, if possible; if not, give way, for it is written: "Give place to wrath".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:14
verses.text: Jacob dutifully gave way to his brother when angry, and to Rebecca; that is to say, taught by counsels of patience, he preferred to go away and live in foreign lands, rather than to arouse his brother's anger; and then to return only when he thought his brother was appeased.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:15
verses.text: Thus it was that he found such great grace with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:16
verses.text: With what offers of willing service, with what gifts, did he reconcile his brother to himself again, so that he should not remember the blessing which had been taken away from him, but should only remember the reparation now offered?  92.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:17
verses.text: If, then, anger has got the start, and has already taken possession of thy mind, and mounted into thy heart, forsake not thy ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:18
verses.text: Thy ground is patience, it is wisdom, it is reason, it is the allaying of indignation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:19
verses.text: And if the stubbornness of thy opponent rouses thee, and his perverseness drives thee to indignation: if thou canst not calm thy mind, check at least thy tongue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:20
verses.text: For so it is written: "Keep thy tongue from evil, and thy lips that they speak no guile.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:21
verses.text: Seek peace and pursue it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:22
verses.text: See the peace of holy Jacob, how great it was! First, then, calm thy mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:23
verses.text: If thou canst not do this, put a restraint upon thy tongue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:24
verses.text: Lastly, omit not to seek for reconciliation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:25
verses.text: These ideas the speakers of the world have borrowed from us, and have set down in their writings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:26
verses.text: But he who said it first has the credit of understanding its meaning.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:28
verses.text: Let us then avoid or at any rate check anger, so that we may not lose our share of praise, nor yet add to our list of sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:29
verses.text: It is no light thing to calm one's anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:30
verses.text: It is no less difficult a thing than it is not to be roused at all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:31
verses.text: The one is an act of our own will, the other is an effect of nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:32
verses.text: So quarrels among boys are harmless, and have more of a pleasant than a bitter character about them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:33
verses.text: And if boys quickly come to quarrel one with the other, they are easily calmed down again, and quickly come together with even greater friendliness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:34
verses.text: They do not know how to act deceitfully and artfully.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:35
verses.text: Do not condemn these children, of whom the Lord says: "Except ye be converted and become as this child, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:36
verses.text: So also the Lord Himself, Who is the Power of God, as a Boy, when He was reviled, reviled not again,  when He was struck, struck not back.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:37
verses.text: Set then thy mind on this—like a child never to keep an injury in mind, never to show malice, but that all things may be done blamelessly by thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:38
verses.text: Regard not the return made thee by others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:39
verses.text: Hold thy ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:40
verses.text: Guard the simplicity and purity of thy heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:41
verses.text: Answer not an angry man according to his anger, nor a foolish man according to his folly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:42
verses.text: One fault quickly calls forth another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:43
verses.text: If stones are rubbed together, does not fire break forth?  94.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:44
verses.text: The heathen—(they are wont to exaggerate everything in speaking)—make much of the saying of the philosopher Archites of Tarentum, which he spoke to his bailiff: "O you wretched man, how I would punish you, if I were not angry".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:45
verses.text: But David already before this had in his indignation held back his armed hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:46
verses.text: How much greater a thing it is not to revile again, than not to avenge oneself! The warriors, too, prepared to take vengeance against Nabal, Abigail restrained by her prayers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:47
verses.text: From whence we perceive that we ought not only to yield to timely entreaties, but also to be pleased with them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:48
verses.text: So much was David pleased that he blessed her who intervened, because he was restrained from his desire for revenge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:49
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:50
verses.text: Already before this he had said of his enemies: "For they cast iniquity upon me, and in their wrath they were grievous to me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:51
verses.text: Let us hear what he said when overwhelmed in wrath: "Who will give me wings like a dove, and I will flee away and be at rest".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:52
verses.text: They kept provoking him to anger, but he sought quietness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:53
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:54
verses.text: He had also said: "Be ye angry and sin not".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:55
verses.text: The moral teacher who knew that the natural disposition should rather be guided by a reasonable course of teaching, than be eradicated, teaches morals, and says: "Be angry where there is a fault against which ye ought to be angry".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:56
verses.text: For it is impossible not to be roused up by the baseness of many things; otherwise we might be accounted, not virtuous, but apathetic and neglectful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:57
verses.text: Be angry therefore, so that ye keep free from fault, or, in other words: If ye are angry, do not sin, but overcome wrath with reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:58
verses.text: Or one might put it thus: If ye are angry, be angry with yourselves, because ye are roused, and ye will not sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:59
verses.text: For he who is angry with himself, because he has been so easily roused, ceases to be angry with another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:60
verses.text: But he who wishes to prove his anger is righteous only gets the more inflamed, and quickly falls into sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:61
verses.text: "Better is he," as Solomon says, "that restraineth his anger, than he that taketh a city," for anger leads astray even brave men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:62
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:63
verses.text: We ought therefore to take care that we do not get into a flurry, before reason prepares our minds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:64
verses.text: For oftentimes anger or distress or fear of death almost deprives the soul of life, and beats it down by a sudden blow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:65
verses.text: It is therefore a good thing to anticipate this by reflection, and to exercise the mind by considering the matter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 21:66
verses.text: So the mind will not be roused by any sudden disturbance, but will grow calm, being held in by the yoke and reins of reason.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:2
verses.text: On reflection and passion, and on observing propriety of speech, both in ordinary conversation and in holding discussions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:4
verses.text: There are two kinds of mental motions—those of reflection and of passion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:5
verses.text: The one has to do with reflection, the other with passion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:6
verses.text: There is no confusion one with the other, for they are markedly different and unlike.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:7
verses.text: Reflection has to search and as it were to grind out the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:8
verses.text: Passion prompts and stimulates us to do something.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:9
verses.text: Thus by its very nature reflection diffuses tranquillity and calm; and passion sends forth the impulse to act.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:10
verses.text: Let us then be ready to allow reflection on good things to enter into our mind, and to make passion submit to reason (if indeed we wish to direct our minds to guard what is seemly), lest desire for anything should shut out reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:11
verses.text: Rather let reason test and see what befits virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:13
verses.text: And since we have said that we must aim at the observance of what is seemly, so as to know what is the due measure in our words and deeds, and as order in speech rather than in action comes first; speech is divided into two kinds: first, as it is used in friendly conversation, and then in the treatment and discussion of matters of faith and justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:14
verses.text: In either case we must take care that there is no irritation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:15
verses.text: Our language should be mild and quiet, and full of kindness and courtesy and free from insult.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:16
verses.text: Let there be no obstinate disputes in our familiar conversations, for they are wont  only to bring up useless subjects, rather than to supply anything useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:17
verses.text: Let there be discussion without wrath, urbanity without bitterness, warning without sharpness, advice without giving offence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:18
verses.text: And as in every action of our life we ought to take heed to this, in order that no overpowering impulse of our mind may ever shut out reason (let us always keep a place for counsel), so, too, ought we to observe that rule in our language, so that neither wrath nor hatred may be aroused, and that we may not show any signs of our greed or sloth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:20
verses.text: Let our language be of this sort, more especially when we are speaking of the holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:21
verses.text: For of what ought we to speak more often than of the best subject of conversation, of its exhortation to watchfulness, its care for good instruction? Let us have a reason for beginning, and let our end be within due limits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:22
verses.text: For a speech that is wearisome only stirs up anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:23
verses.text: But surely it is most unseemly that when every kind of conversation generally gives additional pleasure, this should give cause of offence!  101.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:24
verses.text: The treatment also of such subjects as the teaching of faith, instruction on self-restraint, discussion on justice, exhortation to activity, must not be taken up by us and fully gone into all at one time, but must be carried on in course, so far as we can do it, and as the subject-matter of the passage allows.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:25
verses.text: Our discourse must not be too lengthy, nor too soon cut short, for fear the former should leave behind it a feeling of aversion, and the latter produce carelessness and neglect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 22:26
verses.text: The address should be plain and simple, clear and evident, full of dignity and weight; it should not be studied or too refined, nor yet, on the other hand, be unpleasing and rough in style.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:2
verses.text: Jests, although at times they may be quite proper, should be altogether banished among clerics.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:3
verses.text: The voice should be plain and frank.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:5
verses.text: Men of the world give many further rules about the way to speak, which I think we may pass over; as, for instance, the way jesting should be conducted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:6
verses.text: For though at times jests may be proper and pleasant, yet they are unsuited to the clerical life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:7
verses.text: For how can we adopt those things which we do not find in the holy Scriptures?  103.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:8
verses.text: We must also take care that in relating stories we do not alter the earnest purpose of the harder rule we have set before us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:9
verses.text: "Woe unto you that laugh, for ye shall weep," says the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:10
verses.text: Do we seek for something to laugh at, that laughing here we may weep hereafter? I think we ought to avoid not only broad jokes, but all kinds of jests, unless perchance it is not unfitting at the time for our conversation to be agreeable and pleasant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:12
verses.text: In speaking of the voice, I certainly think it ought to be plain and clear.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:13
verses.text: That it should be musical is a gift of nature, and is not to be won by exertion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:14
verses.text: Let it be distinct in its pronunciation and full of a manly vigour, but let it be free from a rough and rustic twang.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 23:15
verses.text: See, too, that it does not assume a theatrical accent, but rather keeps true to the inner meaning of the words it utters.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:2
verses.text: There are three things to be noticed in the actions of our life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:3
verses.text: First, our passions are to be controlled by our reason; next, we ought to observe a suitable moderation in our desires; and, lastly, everything ought to be done at the right time and in the proper order.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:4
verses.text: All these qualities shone forth so conspicuously in the holy men of Old Testament time, that it is evident they were well furnished with what men call the cardinal virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:6
verses.text: I think I have said enough on the art of speaking.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:7
verses.text: Let us now consider what beseems an active life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:8
verses.text: We note that there are three things to be regarded in connection with this subject.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:9
verses.text: One is, that passion should not resist our reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:10
verses.text: In that way only can our duties be brought into line with what is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:11
verses.text: For if passion yields to reason we can easily maintain what is seemly in our duties.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:12
verses.text: Next, we must take care lest, either by showing greater zeal or less than the matter we take up demands, we look as though we were taking up a small matter with great parade or were treating a great matter with but little care.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:13
verses.text: Thirdly, as regards moderation in our endeavours and works, and also with regard to order in doing things and in the right timing of things, I think that everything should be open and straightforward.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:15
verses.text: But first comes that which I may call the foundation of all, namely, that our passions should obey our reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:16
verses.text: The second  and third are really the same—moderation in either case.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:17
verses.text: There is room with us for the survey of a pleasing form, which is accounted beauty, and the consideration of dignity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:18
verses.text: Next follows the consideration of the order and the timing of things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:19
verses.text: These, then, are the three points, and we must see whether we can show them in perfection in any one of the saints.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:21
verses.text: First there is our father Abraham, who was formed and called for the instruction of generations to come.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:22
verses.text: When bidden to go forth from his own country and kindred and from his father's house, though bound and held back by many ties of relationship, did he not give proof that in him passion was subject to reason? Who does not delight in the sweet charms of his native land, his kindred, and his own home? Their sweetness then delighted him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:23
verses.text: But the thought of the heavenly command and of an eternal reward influenced him more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:24
verses.text: Did he not reflect that he could not take his wife with him without the greatest danger, unused as she was to hardships, and so tender to bear insults, and so beautiful as to be likely to arouse the lust of profligate men? Yet he decided somewhat deliberately to undergo all this rather than to escape it by making excuses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:25
verses.text: Lastly, when he had gone into Egypt, he advised her to say she was his sister, not his wife.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:27
verses.text: See here what passions are at work! He feared for the chastity of his wife, he feared for his own safety, he had his suspicions about the lust of the Egyptians, and yet the reasonableness of performing his duty to God prevailed with him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:28
verses.text: For he thought that by the favour of God he could be safe everywhere, but if he offended the Lord he could not abide unharmed even at home.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:29
verses.text: Thus reason conquered passion, and brought it into subjection to itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:30
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:31
verses.text: When his nephew was taken captive, without being terrified or dismayed at the hordes of so many kings, he resumed the war.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:32
verses.text: And after the victory was gained he refused his share of the spoil, which he himself had really won.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:33
verses.text: Also, when a son was promised him, though he thought of the lost vigour of his body, now as good as dead, and the barrenness of his wife, and his own great age, he believed God, though it was against the law of nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:34
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:35
verses.text: Note how everything meets together here.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:36
verses.text: Passion was not wanting, but it was checked.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:37
verses.text: Here was a mind equable in action, which neither treated great things as unimportant or little things as great.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:38
verses.text: Here there was moderation in different affairs, order in things, fitness of occasion, due measure in words.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:39
verses.text: He was foremost in faith, conspicuous in virtue, vigorous in battle, in victory not greedy, at home hospitable, and to his wife attentive.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:40
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:41
verses.text: Jacob also, his holy grandson, loved to pass his time at home free from danger; but his mother wished him to live in foreign parts, and so give place to his brother's anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:42
verses.text: Sound counsels prevailed over natural feelings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:43
verses.text: An exile from home, banished from his parents, yet everywhere, in all he did, he observed due measure, such as was fitting, and made use of his opportunities at the right time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:44
verses.text: So dear was he to his parents at home, that the one, moved by the promptness of his compliance, gave him his blessing, the other inclined towards him with tender love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:45
verses.text: In the judgment of his brother, also, he was placed first, when he thought that he ought to give up his food to his brother.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:46
verses.text: For though according to his natural inclinations he wished for food, yet when asked for it he gave it up from a feeling of brotherly affection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:47
verses.text: He was a faithful shepherd of the flock for his master, an attentive son-in-law to his father-in-law; he was active in work, sparing in his meals, conspicuous in making amends, lavish in repaying.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:48
verses.text: Nay, so well did he calm his brother's anger that he received his favour, though he had feared his enmity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:49
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:50
verses.text: What shall I say of Joseph? He certainly had a longing for freedom, and yet endured the bonds of servitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:51
verses.text: How meek he was in slavery, how unchanging in virtue, how kindly in prison! Wise, too, in interpreting, and self-restrained in exercising his power! In the time of plenty was he not careful? In the time of famine was he not fair? Did he not praiseworthily do everything in order, and use opportunities at their season; giving justice to his people by the restraining guidance of his office?  113.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:52
verses.text: Job also, both in prosperity and adversity, was blameless, patient, pleasing, and acceptable to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:53
verses.text: He was harassed with pain, yet could find consolation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:54
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:55
verses.text: David also was brave in war, patient in time of adversity, peaceful at Jerusalem, in the hour of victory merciful, on committing sin repentant, in his old age foreseeing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:56
verses.text: He preserved due measure in his actions, and  took his opportunities as they came.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:57
verses.text: He has set them down in the songs of succeeding years; and so it seems to me that he has by his life no less than by the sweetness of his hymns poured forth an undying song of his own merits to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:58
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 24:59
verses.text: What duty connected with the chief virtues was wanting in these men? In the first place they showed prudence, which is exercised in the search of the truth, and which imparts a desire for full knowledge; next, justice, which assigns each man his own, does not claim another's, and disregards its own advantage, so as to guard the rights of all; thirdly, fortitude, which both in warfare and at home is conspicuous in greatness of mind and distinguishes itself in the strength of the body; fourthly, temperance, which preserves the right method and order in all things that we think should either be done or said.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:2
verses.text: A reason is given why this book did not open with a discussion of the above-mentioned virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:3
verses.text: It is also concisely pointed out that the same virtues existed in the ancient fathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:5
verses.text: Perhaps, as the different classes of duties are derived from these four virtues, some one may say that they ought to have been described first of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:6
verses.text: But it would have been artificial to have given a definition of duty at the outset, and then to have gone on to divide it up into various classes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:7
verses.text: We have avoided what is artificial, and have put forward the examples of the fathers of old.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:8
verses.text: These certainly offer us no uncertainty as regards our understanding them, and give us no room for subtlety in our discussion of them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:9
verses.text: Let the life of the fathers, then, be for us a mirror of virtue, not a mere collection of shrewd and clever acts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:10
verses.text: Let us show reverence in following them, not mere cleverness in discussing them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:12
verses.text: Prudence held the first place in holy Abraham.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:13
verses.text: For of him the Scriptures say: "Abraham believed God, and that was counted to him for righteousness;" for no one is prudent who knows not God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:14
verses.text: Again: "The fool hath said, There is no God;" for a wise man would not say so.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:15
verses.text: How is he wise who looks not for his Maker, but says to a stone: "Thou art my father"? Who says to the devil as the Manichaean does: "Thou art the author of my being"? How is Arius wise, who prefers an imperfect and inferior creator to one who is a true and perfect one? How can Marcion or Eunomius be wise, who prefer to have an evil rather than a good God? And how can he be wise who does not fear his God? For: "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:16
verses.text: Elsewhere, too, it stands: "The wise turn not aside from the mouth of the Lord, but come near Him in their confession of His greatness".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:17
verses.text: So when the Scripture says: "It was counted to him for righteousness," that brought to him the grace of another virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:19
verses.text: The chief amongst ourselves have stated that prudence lies in the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:20
verses.text: But who of them all excelled Abraham, David, or Solomon in this? Then they go on to say that justice has regard to the whole community of the human race.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:21
verses.text: So David said: "He hath dispersed abroad and given to the poor, His righteousness remaineth for ever".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:22
verses.text: The just man has pity, the just man lends.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:23
verses.text: The whole world of riches lies at the feet of the wise and the just.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:24
verses.text: The just man regards what belongs to all as his own, and his own as common property.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:25
verses.text: The man just accuses himself rather than others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:26
verses.text: For he is just who does not spare himself, and who does not suffer his secret actions to be concealed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:27
verses.text: See now how just Abraham was! In his old age he begat a son according to promise, and when the Lord demanded him for sacrifice he did not think he ought to refuse him, although he was his only son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:28
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:29
verses.text: Note here all these four virtues in one act.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:30
verses.text: It was wise to believe God, and not to put love for his son before the commands of his Creator.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:31
verses.text: It was just to give back  what had been received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:32
verses.text: It was brave to restrain natural feelings by reason.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:33
verses.text: The father led the victim; the son asked where it was: the father's feelings were hardly tried, but were not overcome.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:34
verses.text: The son said again: "My father," and thus pierced his father's heart, though without weakening his devotion to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:35
verses.text: The fourth virtue, temperance, too, was there.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:36
verses.text: Being just he preserved due measure in his piety, and order in all he had to carry out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:37
verses.text: And so in bringing what was needed for the sacrifice, in lighting the fire, in binding his son, in drawing the knife, in performing the sacrifice in due order; thus he merited as his reward that he might keep his son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:39
verses.text: Is there greater wisdom than holy Jacob's, who saw God face to face and won a blessing? Can there be higher justice than his in dividing with his brother what he had acquired, and offering it as a gift? What greater fortitude than his in striving with God? What moderation so true as his, who acted with such moderation as regards time and place, as to prefer to hide his daughter's shame rather than to avenge himself? For being set in the midst of foes, he thought it better to gain their affections than to concentrate their hate on himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:40
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:41
verses.text: How wise also was Noah, who built the whole of the ark! How just again! For he alone, preserved of all to be the father of the human race, was made a survivor of past generations, and the author of one to come; he was born, too, rather for the world and the universe than for himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 25:42
verses.text: How brave he was to overcome the flood! how temperate to endure it! When he had entered the ark, with what moderation he passed the time! When he sent forth the raven and the dove, when he received them on their return, when he took the opportunity of leaving the ark, with what moderation did he make use of these occasions!.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:2
verses.text: In investigating the truth the philosophers have broken through their own rules.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:3
verses.text: Moses, however, showed himself more wise than they.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:4
verses.text: The greater the dignity of wisdom, the more earnestly must we strive to gain it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:5
verses.text: Nature herself urges us all to do this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:7
verses.text: It is said, therefore, that in investigating the truth, we must observe what is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:8
verses.text: We ought to look for what is true with the greatest care.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:9
verses.text: We must not put forward falsehood for truth, nor hide the truth in darkness, nor fill the mind with idle, involved, or doubtful matters.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:10
verses.text: What so unseemly as to worship a wooden thing, which men themselves have made? What shows such darkness as to discuss subjects connected with geometry and astronomy (which they approve of), to measure the depths of space, to shut up heaven and earth within the limits of fixed numbers, to leave aside the grounds of salvation and to seek for error?  123.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:11
verses.text: Moses, learned as he was in all the wisdom of the Egyptians, did not approve of those things, but thought that kind of wisdom both harmful and foolish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:12
verses.text: Turning away therefrom, he sought God with all the desire of his heart, and thus saw, questioned, heard Him when He spoke.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:13
verses.text: Who is more wise than he whom God taught, and who brought to nought all the wisdom of the Egyptians, and all the powers of their craft by the might of his works? He did not treat things unknown as well known, and so rashly accept them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:14
verses.text: Yet these philosophers, though they do not consider it contrary to nature, nor shameful for themselves to worship, and to ask help from an idol which knows nothing, teach us that these two things mentioned in the words just spoken, which are in accordance both with nature and with virtue, ought to be avoided.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:16
verses.text: The loftier the virtue of wisdom is, the more I say we ought to strive for it, so that we may be able to attain to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:17
verses.text: And that we may have no ideas which are contrary to nature, or are disgraceful, or unfitting, we ought to give two things, that is, time and care, to considering matters for the sake of investigating them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:18
verses.text: For there is nothing in which man excels all other living creatures more than in the fact that he has reason, seeks out the origin of things, thinks that the Author of his being should be searched out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:19
verses.text: For in His hand is our life and death; He rules this world by His nod.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:20
verses.text: And to Him we know that we must give a reason for our actions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:21
verses.text: For there is nothing which is more of a help to a good life than to believe that He will be our judge, Whom hidden things do not escape, and unseemly things offend, and good deeds delight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:23
verses.text: In all men, then, there lies, in accordance with human nature, a desire to search out the truth, which leads us on to have a longing for knowledge and learning, and  infuses into us a wish to seek after it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:24
verses.text: To excel in this seems a noble thing to mankind; but there are only few who attain to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:25
verses.text: And they, by deep thought, by careful deliberation, spend no little labour so as to be able to attain to that blessed and virtuous life, and to approach its likeness in their actions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:26
verses.text: "For not he that saith to Me Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven, but he that doeth those things that I say".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 26:27
verses.text: To have a desire for knowledge without actions to correspond—well! I do not know whether that carries anything more with it.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:2
verses.text: The first source of duty is prudence, from whence spring three other virtues; and they cannot be separated or torn asunder, since they are mutually connected one with the other.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:4
verses.text: The first source of duty, then, is prudence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:5
verses.text: For what is more of a duty than to give to the Creator all one's devotion and reverence? This source, however, is drawn off into other virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:6
verses.text: For justice cannot exist without prudence, since it demands no small amount of prudence to see whether a thing is just or unjust.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:7
verses.text: A mistake on either side is very serious.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:8
verses.text: "For he that says a just man is unjust, or an unjust man is just, is accursed with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:9
verses.text: Wherefore does justice abound unto the wicked?" says Solomon.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:10
verses.text: Nor, on the other hand, can prudence exist without justice, for piety towards God is the beginning of understanding.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:11
verses.text: On which we notice that this is a borrowed rather than an original idea among the worldly wise, for piety is the foundation of all virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:13
verses.text: But the piety of justice is first directed towards God; secondly, towards one's country; next, towards parents; lastly, towards all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:14
verses.text: This, too, is in accordance with the guidance of nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:15
verses.text: From the beginning of life, when understanding first begins to be infused into us, we love life as the gift of God, we love our country and our parents; lastly, our companions, with whom we like to associate.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:16
verses.text: Hence arises true love, which prefers others to self, and seeks not its own, wherein lies the pre-eminence of justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:18
verses.text: It is ingrained in all living creatures, first of all, to preserve their own safety, to guard against what is harmful, to strive for what is advantageous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:19
verses.text: They seek food and converts, whereby they may protect themselves from dangers, storms, and sun,—all which is a mark of prudence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:20
verses.text: Next we find that all the different creatures are by nature wont to herd together, at first with fellows of their own class and sort, then also with others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:21
verses.text: So we see oxen delighted to be in herds, horses in droves, and especially like with like, stags, also, in company with stags and often with men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:22
verses.text: And what should I say on their desire to have young, and on their offspring, or even on their passions, wherein the likeness of justice is conspicuous?  129.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:23
verses.text: It is clear, then, that these and the remaining virtues are related to one another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:24
verses.text: For courage, which in war preserves one's country from the barbarians, or at home defends the weak, or comrades from robbers, is full of justice; and to know on what plan to defend and to give help, how to make use of opportunities of time and place, is the part of prudence and moderation, and temperance itself cannot observe due measure without prudence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:25
verses.text: To know a fit opportunity, and to make return according to what is right, belongs to justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 27:26
verses.text: In all these, too, large-heartedness is necessary, and fortitude of mind, and often of body, so that we may carry out what we wish.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:2
verses.text: A community rests upon justice and good-will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:3
verses.text: Two parts of the former, revenge and private possession, are not recognized by Christians.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:4
verses.text: What the Stoics say about common property and mutual help has been borrowed from the sacred writings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:5
verses.text: The greatness of the glory of justice, and what hinders access to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:7
verses.text: Justice, then, has to do with the society of the human race, and the community at large.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:8
verses.text: For that which holds society together is divided into two parts,—justice and good-will, which also is called liberality and kindness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:9
verses.text: Justice seems to me the loftier, liberality the more pleasing, of the two.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:10
verses.text: The one gives judgment, the other shows goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:12
verses.text: But that very thing is excluded with us which philosophers think to be the office of justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:13
verses.text: For they say that the first expression of justice is, to hurt no one, except  when driven to it by wrongs received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:14
verses.text: This is put aside by the authority of the Gospel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:15
verses.text: For the Scripture wills that the Spirit of the Son of Man should be in us, Who came to give grace, not to bring harm.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:17
verses.text: Next they considered it consonant with justice that one should treat common, that is, public property as public, and private as private.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:18
verses.text: But this is not even in accord with nature, for nature has poured forth all things for all men for common use.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:19
verses.text: God has ordered all things to be produced, so that there should be food in common to all, and that the earth should be a common possession for all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:20
verses.text: Nature, therefore, has produced a common right for all, but greed has made it a right for a few.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:21
verses.text: Here, too, we are told that the Stoics taught that all things which are produced on the earth are created for the use of men, but that men are born for the sake of men, so that mutually one may be of advantage to another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:23
verses.text: But whence have they got such ideas but out of the holy Scriptures?
