For Moses wrote that God said: "Let us make man in our image, after our likeness, and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:24
verses.text: And David said: "Thou hast put all things under his feet; all sheep and oxen, yea, and the beasts of the field, the fowls of the air, and the fishes of the sea".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:25
verses.text: So these philosophers have learnt from our writings that all things were made subject to man, and, therefore, they think that all things were produced also for man's sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:27
verses.text: That man was made for the sake of man we find stated also in the books of Moses, when the Lord says: "It is not good that man should be alone, let us make him an helpmeet for him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:28
verses.text: Thus the woman was given to the man to help him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:29
verses.text: She should bear him children, that one man might always be a help to another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:30
verses.text: Again, before the woman was formed, it was said of Adam: "There was not found an help-meet for him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:31
verses.text: For one man could not have proper help but from another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:32
verses.text: Amongst all the living creatures, therefore, there was none meet for him, or, to put it plainly, none to be his helper.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:33
verses.text: Hence a woman was looked for to help him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:34
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:35
verses.text: Thus, in accordance with the will of God and the union of nature, we ought to be of mutual help one to the other, and to vie with each other in doing duties, to lay all our advantages as it were before all, and (to use the words of Scripture) to bring help one to the other from a feeling of devotion or of duty, by giving money, or by doing something, at any rate in some way or other; so that the charm of human fellowship may ever grow sweeter amongst us, and none may ever be recalled from their duty by the fear of danger, but rather account all things, whether good or evil, as their own concern.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:36
verses.text: Thus holy Moses feared not to undertake terrible wars for his people's sake, nor was he afraid of the arms of the mightiest kings, nor yet was he frightened at the savagery of barbarian nations.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:37
verses.text: He put on one side the thought of his own safety so as to give freedom to the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:39
verses.text: Great, then, is the glory of justice; for she, existing rather for the good of others than of self, is an aid to the bonds of union and fellowship amongst us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:40
verses.text: She holds so high a place that she has all things laid under her authority, and further can bring help to others and supply money; nor does she refuse her services, but even undergoes dangers for others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:41
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:42
verses.text: Who would not gladly climb and hold the heights of this virtue, were it not that greed weakens and lessens the power of such a virtue? For as long as we want to add to our possessions and to heap up money, to take into our possession fresh lands, and to be the richest of all, we have cast aside the form of justice and have lost the blessing of kindness towards all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:43
verses.text: How can he be just that tries to take from another what he wants for himself?  138.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:44
verses.text: The desire to gain power also enervates the perfect strength and beauty of justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 28:45
verses.text: For how can he, who attempts to bring others under his own power, come forward on behalf of others? And how can a man help the weak against the strong, when he himself aspires to great power at the cost of liberty?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:2
verses.text: Justice should be observed even in war and with enemies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:3
verses.text: This is proved by the example of Moses and Elisha.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:4
verses.text: The ancient writers learnt in turn from the Hebrews to call their enemies by a gentler term.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:5
verses.text: Lastly, the foundation of justice rests on faith, and its symmetry is perfect in the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:7
verses.text: How great a thing justice is can be  gathered from the fact that there is no place, nor person, nor time, with which it has nothing to do.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:8
verses.text: It must even be preserved in all dealings with enemies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:9
verses.text: For instance, if the day or the spot for a battle has been agreed upon with them, it would be considered an act against justice to occupy the spot beforehand, or to anticipate the time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:10
verses.text: For there is some difference whether one is overcome in some battle by a severe engagement, or by superior skill, or by a mere chance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:11
verses.text: But a deeper vengeance is taken on fiercer foes, and on those that are false as well as on those who have done greater wrongs, as was the case with the Midianites.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:12
verses.text: For they had made many of the Jewish people to sin through their women; for which reason the anger of the Lord was poured out upon the people of our fathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:13
verses.text: Thus it came about that Moses when victorious allowed none of them to live.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:14
verses.text: On the other hand, Joshua did not attack the Gibeonites, who had tried the people of our fathers with guile rather than with war, but punished them by laying on them a law of bondage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:15
verses.text: Elisha again would not allow the king of Israel to slay the Syrians when he wished to do so.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:16
verses.text: He had brought them into the city, when they were besieging him, after he had struck them with instantaneous blindness, so that they could not see where they were going.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:17
verses.text: For he said: "Thou shalt not smite those whom thou hast not taken captive with thy spear and with thy sword.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:18
verses.text: Set before them bread and water, that they may eat and drink and return and go to their own home".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:19
verses.text: Incited by their kind treatment they should show forth to the world the kindness they had received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:20
verses.text: "Thus" (we read) "there came no more the bands of Syria into the land of Israel".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:22
verses.text: If, then, justice is binding, even in war, how much more ought we to observe it in time of peace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:23
verses.text: Such favour the prophet showed to those who came to seize him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:24
verses.text: We read that the king of Syria had sent his army to lie in wait for him, for he had learnt that it was Elisha who had made known to all his plans and consultations.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:25
verses.text: And Gehazi the prophet's servant, seeing the army, began to fear that his life was in danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:26
verses.text: But the prophet said to him: "Fear not, for they that be with us are more than they that be with them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:27
verses.text: And when the prophet asked that the eyes of his servant might be opened, they were opened.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:28
verses.text: Then Gehazi saw the whole mountain full of horses and chariots round about Elisha.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:29
verses.text: As they came down to him the prophet says: "Smite, O God, the army of Syria with blindness".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:30
verses.text: And this prayer being granted, he says to the Syrians: "Follow me, and I will bring you to the man whom ye seek".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:31
verses.text: Then saw they Elisha, whom they were endeavouring to lay hold of, and seeing him they could not hold him fast.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:32
verses.text: It is clear from this that faith and justice should be observed even in war; and that it could not but be a disgraceful thing if faith were violated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:33
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:34
verses.text: So also the ancients used to give their foes a less harsh name, and called them strangers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:35
verses.text: For enemies used to be called strangers after the customs of old.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:36
verses.text: This too we can say they adopted from our writings; for the Hebrews used to call their foes "allophyllos," that is, when put into Latin, "alienigenas" (of another race).

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:37
verses.text: For so we read in the first book of Kings: "It came to pass in those days that they of another race put themselves in array against Israel".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:39
verses.text: The foundation of justice therefore is faith, for the hearts of the just dwell on faith, and the just man that accuses himself builds justice on faith, for his justice becomes plain when he confesses the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:40
verses.text: So the Lord saith through Isaiah: "Behold, I lay a stone for a foundation in Sion".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:41
verses.text: This means Christ as the foundation of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:42
verses.text: For Christ is the object of faith to all; but the Church is as it were the outward form of justice, she is the common right of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:43
verses.text: For all in common she prays, for all in common she works, in the temptations of all she is tried.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:44
verses.text: So he who denies himself is indeed a just man, is indeed worthy of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:45
verses.text: For this reason Paul has made Christ to be the foundation, so that we may build upon Him the works of justice, whilst faith is the foundation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 29:46
verses.text: In our works, then, if they are evil, there appears unrighteousness; if they are good, justice.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:2
verses.text: On kindness and its several parts, namely, good-will and liberality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:3
verses.text: How they are to be combined.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:4
verses.text: What else is further needed for any one to show liberality in a praiseworthy manner.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:6
verses.text: Now we can go on to speak of kindness, which breaks up into two parts, goodwill and liberality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:7
verses.text: Kindness to exist in perfection must consist of these two qualities.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:8
verses.text: It is not enough just to wish well; we must  also do well.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:9
verses.text: Nor, again, is it enough to do well, unless this springs from a good source even from a good will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:10
verses.text: "For God loveth a cheerful giver".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:11
verses.text: If we act unwillingly, what is our reward? Wherefore the Apostle, speaking generally, says: "If I do this thing willingly, I have a reward, but if unwillingly, a dispensation is given unto me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:12
verses.text: In the Gospel, also, we have received many rules of just liberality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:14
verses.text: It is thus a glorious thing to wish well, and to give freely, with the one desire to do good and not to do harm.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:15
verses.text: For if we were to think it our duty to give the means to an extravagant man to live extravagantly, or to an adulterer to pay for his adultery, it would not be an act of kindness, for there would be no good-will in it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:16
verses.text: We should be doing harm, not good, to another if we gave him money to aid him in plotting against his country, or in attempting to get together at our expense some abandoned men to attack the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:17
verses.text: Nor, again, does it look like liberality to help one who presses very hardly on widows and orphans, or attempts to seize on their property with any show of violence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:19
verses.text: It is no sign of a liberal spirit to extort from one what we give to another, or to gain money unjustly, and then to think it can be well spent, unless we act as Zacchaeus did, and restore fourfold what we have taken from him whom we have robbed, and make up for such heathenish crimes by the zeal of our faith and by true Christian labour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:20
verses.text: Our liberality must have some sure foundation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:22
verses.text: The first thing necessary is to do kindness in good faith, and not to act falsely when the offering is made.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:23
verses.text: Never let us say we are doing more, when we are really doing less.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:24
verses.text: What need is there to speak at all? In a promise a cheat lies hid.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:25
verses.text: It is in our power to give what we like.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:26
verses.text: Cheating shatters the foundation, and so destroys the work.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:27
verses.text: Did Peter grow angry only so far as to desire that Ananias and his wife should be slain? Certainly not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:28
verses.text: He wished that others, through knowing their example, should not perish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:29
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:30
verses.text: Nor is it a real act of liberality if thou givest for the sake of boasting about it, rather than for mercy's sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:31
verses.text: Thy inner feelings give the name to thy acts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:32
verses.text: As it comes forth from thee, so will others regard it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:33
verses.text: See what a true judge thou hast! He consults with thee how to take up thy work, and first of all he questions thy mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:34
verses.text: "Let not," he says, "thy left hand know what thy right hand doth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:35
verses.text: This does not refer to our actual bodies, but means: Let not him who is of one mind with thee, not even thy brother, know what thou doest, lest thou shouldst lose the fruit of thy reward hereafter by seeking here thy price in boastfulness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:36
verses.text: But that liberality is real where a man hides what he does in silence, and secretly assists the needs of individuals, whom the mouth of the poor, and not his own lips, praises.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:37
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:38
verses.text: Perfect liberality is proved by its good faith, the case it helps, the time and place when and where it is shown.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:39
verses.text: But first we must always see that we help those of the household of faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:40
verses.text: It is a serious fault if a believer is in want, and thou knowest it, or if thou knowest that he is without means, that he is hungry, that he suffer distress, especially if he is ashamed of his need.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:41
verses.text: It is a great fault if he is overwhelmed by the imprisonment or false accusation of his family, and thou dost not come to his help.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:42
verses.text: If he is in prison, and—upright though he is—has to suffer pain and punishment for some debt (for though we ought to show mercy to all, yet we ought to show it especially to an upright man); if in the time of his trouble he obtains nothing from thee; if in the time of danger, when he is carried off to die, thy money seems more to thee than the life of a dying man; what a sin is that to thee! Wherefore Job says beautifully: "Let the blessing of him that was ready to perish come upon me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:43
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:44
verses.text: God, indeed, is not a respecter of persons, for He knows all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:45
verses.text: And we, indeed, ought to show mercy to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:46
verses.text: But as many try to get help on false pretences, and make out that they are miserably off; therefore where the case is plain and the person well known, and no time is to be lost, mercy ought to be shown more readily.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:47
verses.text: For the Lord is not exacting to demand the utmost.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:48
verses.text: Blessed, indeed, is he who forsakes all and follows Him, but blessed also is he who does what he can to the best of his powers with what he has.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:49
verses.text: The Lord preferred the two mites of the widow to all the gifts of the rich, for she gave all that she had, but they only gave a small part out of all their abundance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:50
verses.text: It is the intention, therefore, that makes the gift valuable or poor, and gives to things their value.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:51
verses.text: The Lord does not want us to give away all our goods at once, but to impart them little by little; unless, indeed, our case is like that of Elisha, who  killed his oxen, and fed the people on what he had, so that no household cares might hold him back, and that he might give up all things, and devote himself to the prophetic teaching.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:52
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:53
verses.text: True liberality also must be tested in this way: that we despise not our nearest relatives, if we know they are in want.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:54
verses.text: For it is better for thee to help thy kindred who feel the shame of asking help from others, or of going to another to beg assistance in their need.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:55
verses.text: Not, however, that they should become rich on what thou couldst otherwise give to the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:56
verses.text: It is the facts of the case we must consider, and not personal feeling.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:57
verses.text: Thou didst not dedicate thyself to the Lord on purpose to make thy family rich, but that thou mightest win eternal life by the fruit of good works, and atone for thy sins by showing mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:58
verses.text: They think perhaps that they are asking but little, but they demand the price thou shouldst pay for thy sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:59
verses.text: They attempt to take away the fruits of thy life, and think they are acting rightly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:60
verses.text: And one accuses thee because thou hast not made him rich, when all the time he wished to cheat thee of the reward of eternal life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:61
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:62
verses.text: So far we have given our advice, now let us look for our authority.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:63
verses.text: First, then, no one ought to be ashamed of becoming poor after being rich, if this happens because he gives freely to the poor; for Christ became poor when He was rich, that through His poverty He might enrich all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:64
verses.text: He has given us a rule to follow, so that we may give a good account of our reduced inheritance; whoever has stayed the hunger of the poor has lightened his distress.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:65
verses.text: "Herein I give my advice," says the Apostle, "for this is expedient for you, that ye should be followers of Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:66
verses.text: Advice is given to the good, but warnings restrain the wrong-doers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:67
verses.text: Again he says, as though to the good: "For ye have begun not only to do, but also to be willing, a year ago".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:68
verses.text: Both of these, and not only one, is the mark of perfection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:69
verses.text: Thus he teaches that liberality without good-will, and good-will without liberality, are neither of them perfect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:70
verses.text: Wherefore he also urges us on to perfection, saying: "Now, therefore, perform the doing of it; that as the will to do it was ready enough in you, so also there may be the will to accomplish it out of that which ye have.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:71
verses.text: For if the will be ready, it is accepted according to that a man hath, and not according to that he hath not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:72
verses.text: But not so that others should have plenty, and ye should be in want: but let there be equality,—your abundance must now serve for their want, that their abundance may serve for your want; that there may be equality, as it is written: "He that gathered much had nothing over, and he that gathered little had no lack".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:73
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:74
verses.text: We notice how the Apostle includes both good-will and liberality, as well as the manner, the fruits of right giving, and the persons concerned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:75
verses.text: The manner certainly, for he gave advice to those not perfect: For only the imperfect suffer anxiety.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:76
verses.text: But if any priest or other cleric, being unwilling to burden the Church, does not give away all that he has, but does honourably what his office demands, he does not seem to me to be imperfect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:77
verses.text: I think also that the Apostle here spoke not of anxiety of mind, but rather of domestic troubles.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:78
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:79
verses.text: And I think it was with reference to the persons concerned that he said: "that your abundance might serve for their want, and their abundance for your want".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:80
verses.text: This means, that the abundance of the people might arouse them to good works, so as to supply the want of food of others; whilst the spiritual abundance of these latter might assist the want of spiritual merits among the people themselves, and so win them a blessing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:81
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:82
verses.text: Wherefore he gave them an excellent example: "He that gathered much had nothing over, and he that gathered little had no lack".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:83
verses.text: That example is a great encouragement to all men to show mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:84
verses.text: For he that possesses much gold has nothing over, for all in this world is as nothing; and he that has little has no lack, for what he loses is nothing already.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:85
verses.text: The whole matter is without loss, for the whole of it is lost already.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:86
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:87
verses.text: We can also rightly understand it thus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:88
verses.text: He that has much, although he does not give away, has nothing over.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:89
verses.text: For however much he gets, he always is in want, because he longs for more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:90
verses.text: And he who has little has no lack, for it does not cost much to feed the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:91
verses.text: In like manner, too, the poor person that gives spiritual blessings in return for money, although he  has much grace, has nothing over.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:92
verses.text: For grace does not burden the mind, but lightens it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:93
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:94
verses.text: It can further be taken in this way: Thou, O man, hast nothing over! For how much hast thou really received, though it may seem much to thee? John, than whom none was greater among those born of woman, yet was less than he who is least in the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:95
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:96
verses.text: Or once more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:97
verses.text: The grace of God is never superabundant, humanly speaking, for it is spiritual.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:98
verses.text: Who can measure its greatness or its breadth, which one cannot see? Faith, if it were as a grain of mustard seed, can transplant mountains—and more than a grain is not granted thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:99
verses.text: If grace dwelt fully in thee, wouldst thou not have to fear lest thy mind should begin to be elated at so great a gift? For there are many who have fallen more terribly, from spiritual heights, than if they had never received grace at all from the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:100
verses.text: And he who has little has no lack, for it is not tangible so as to be divided; and what seems little to him that has is much to him that lacks.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:101
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:102
verses.text: In giving we must also take into consideration age and weakness; sometimes, also, that natural feeling of shame, which indicates good birth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:103
verses.text: One ought to give more to the old who can no longer supply themselves with food by labour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:104
verses.text: So, too, weakness of body must be assisted, and that readily.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:105
verses.text: Again, if any one after being rich has fallen into want, we must assist, especially if he has lost what he had from no sin of his own, but owing to robbery or banishment or false accusation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:106
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:107
verses.text: Perchance some one may say: A blind man sits here in one place, and people pass him by, whilst a strong young man often has something given him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:108
verses.text: That is true; for he comes over people by his importunity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:109
verses.text: That is not because in their judgment he deserves it, but because they are wearied by his begging.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 30:110
verses.text: For the Lord speaks in the Gospel of him who had already closed his door; how that when one knocks at his door very violently, he rises and gives what is wanted, because of his importunity.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:2
verses.text: A kindness received should be returned with a freer hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:3
verses.text: This is shown by the example of the earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:4
verses.text: A passage from Solomon about feasting is adduced to prove the same, and is expounded later in a spiritual sense.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:6
verses.text: It is also right that more regard should be paid to him who has conferred some benefit or gift upon thee, if he ever is reduced to want.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:7
verses.text: For what is so contrary to one's duty as not to return what one has received? Nor do I think that a return of equal value should be made, but a greater.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:8
verses.text: One ought to make up for the enjoyment of a kindness one has received from another, to such an extent as to help that person, even to putting an end to his needs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:9
verses.text: For not to be the better in returning than in conferring a kindness, is to be the inferior; for he who was the first to give was the first in point of time, and also first in showing a kind disposition.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:11
verses.text: Wherefore we must imitate the nature of the earth in this respect, which is wont to return the seed she has received, multiplied a thousand-fold.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:12
verses.text: And so it is written: "As a field is the foolish man, and as a vineyard is the man without sense.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:13
verses.text: If thou leavest him, he will be made desolate".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:14
verses.text: As a field also is the wise man, so as to return the seed given him in fuller measure, as though it had been lent to him on interest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:15
verses.text: The earth either produces fruits of its own accord, or pays back and restores, what it was entrusted with, in fruitful abundance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:16
verses.text: In both these ways a return is due from thee, when thou enterest upon the use of thy father's possession, that thou mayest not be left to lie as an unfruitful field.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:17
verses.text: It may be that a man can make an excuse for not giving anything, but how can he excuse himself for not returning what was given? It is hardly right not to give anything; it is certainly not right to make no return for kindness done to oneself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:19
verses.text: Therefore Solomon says well: "When thou sittest to eat at the table of a ruler consider diligently what is before thee, and put forth thine hand, knowing that it behoves thee to make such preparations.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:20
verses.text: But if thou art insatiable, be not desirous of his dainties, for they have but a deceptive life".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:21
verses.text: I have written these words as I wish that we all should follow them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:22
verses.text: It is a good thing to do a service, but he who knows not how to return one is very hard.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:23
verses.text: The earth herself supplies an example of kindliness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:24
verses.text: She provides fruits of her own accord, which thou didst not sow; she also returns many-fold what she has received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:25
verses.text: It is not right for thee to deny knowledge of money paid in to thee, and how can it be right to let a service done go without notice? In the book of Proverbs also it is said: that the  repayment of kindness has such great power with God, that through it, even in the day of destruction, a man may find grace, though his sins outweigh all else.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:26
verses.text: And why need I bring forward other examples when the Lord Himself promises in the Gospel a fuller reward to the merits of the saints, and exhorts us to do good works, saying: "Forgive, and ye shall be forgiven; give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, shaken together and running over, shall men give into your bosom".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:28
verses.text: But the feasting that Solomon speaks of has not to do with common food only, but it is to be understood as having to do with good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:29
verses.text: For how can the soul be feasted in better wise than on good works; or what can so easily fill the mind of the just as the knowledge of a good work done? What pleasanter food is there than to do the will of God? The Lord has told us that He had this food alone in abundance, as it is written in the Gospel, saying: "My food is to do the will of My Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:30
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:31
verses.text: In this food let us delight of which the prophet says: "Delight thou in the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:32
verses.text: In this food they delight, who have with wonderful knowledge learnt to take in the higher delights; who can know what that delight is which is pure and which can be understood by the mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:33
verses.text: Let us therefore eat the bread of wisdom, and let us be filled with the word of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:34
verses.text: For the life of man made in the image of God consists not in bread alone, but in every word that cometh from God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 31:35
verses.text: About the cup, too, holy Job says, plainly enough: "As the earth waiteth for the rain, so did they for my words".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:2
verses.text: After saying what return must be made for the service of the above-mentioned feast, various reasons for repaying kindness are enumerated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:3
verses.text: Then he speaks in praise of good-will, on its results and its order.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:5
verses.text: It is therefore a good thing for us to be bedewed with the exhortations of the divine Scriptures, and that the word of God should come down upon us like the dew.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:6
verses.text: When, therefore, thou sittest at the table of that great man, understand who that great man is.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:7
verses.text: Set in the paradise of delight and placed at the feast of wisdom, think of what is put before thee! The divine Scriptures are the feast of wisdom, and the single books the various dishes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:8
verses.text: Know, first, what dishes the banquet offers, then stretch forth thy hand, that those things which thou readest, or which thou receivest from the Lord thy God, thou mayest carry out in action, and so by thy duties mayest show forth the grace that was granted thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:9
verses.text: Such was the case with Peter and Paul, who in preaching the Gospel made some return to Him Who freely gave them all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:10
verses.text: So that each of them might say: "By the grace of God I am what I am, and His grace in me was not in vain, but I laboured more abundantly than they all".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:12
verses.text: One repays the fruit of a service done him, and repays it, gold with gold, silver with silver.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:13
verses.text: Another gives his labour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:14
verses.text: Another—and I do not know whether he does not do it in fuller measure—gives but the best wishes of his heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:15
verses.text: But what if there is no opportunity to make a return at hand? If we wish to return a kindness, more depends on the spirit in which we do it than on the amount of our property, whilst people will think more of our good-will, than of our power to make a full return.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:16
verses.text: For a kindness done is regarded in the light of what one has.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:17
verses.text: A great thing, therefore, is good-will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:18
verses.text: For even if it has nothing to give, yet it offers the more, and though there is nothing in its own possession, yet it gives largely to many, and does that, too, without loss to itself, and to the gain of the many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:19
verses.text: Thus good-will is better than liberality itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:20
verses.text: It is richer in character than the other is in gifts; for there are more that need a kindness than there are that have abundance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:22
verses.text: But good-will also goes in conjunction with liberality, for liberality really starts from it, seeing that the habit of giving comes after the desire to give.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:23
verses.text: It exists, however, also separate and distinct.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:24
verses.text: For where liberality is wanting, there good-will abides—the parent as it were of all in common, uniting and binding friendships together.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:25
verses.text: It is faithful in counsel, joyful in times of prosperity, and in times of sorrow sad.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:26
verses.text: So it happens that any one trusts himself to the counsels of a man of good-will rather than to those of a wise one, as David did.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:27
verses.text: For he, though he was the more farseeing, agreed to the counsels of Jonathan, who was the younger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:28
verses.text: Remove good-will out of the reach of men, and it is as though one had withdrawn the sun from the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:29
verses.text: For without it men would no longer care to show the way to the stranger, to recall the  wanderer, to show hospitality (this latter is no small virtue, for on this point Job praised himself, when he said: "At my doors the stranger dwelt not, my gate was open to every one who came"), nor even to give water from the water that flows at their door, or to light another's candle at their own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:30
verses.text: Thus good-will exists in all these, like a fount of waters refreshing the thirsty, and like a light, which, shining forth to others, fails not them who have given a light to others from their own light.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:32
verses.text: There is also liberality springing from good-will, that makes one tear up the bond of a debtor which one holds, without demanding any of the debt back from him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:33
verses.text: Holy Job bids us act thus by his own example.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:34
verses.text: For he that has does not borrow, but he that has not does not put an end to the agreement.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:35
verses.text: Why, then, if thou hast no need, dost thou save up for greedy heirs what thou canst give back immediately, and so get praise for good-will, and that without loss of money?  169.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:36
verses.text: To go to the root of the matter—good-will starts first with those at home, that is with children, parents, brothers, and goes on from one step to another throughout the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:37
verses.text: Having started from Paradise, it has filled the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:38
verses.text: For God set the feeling of good-will in the man and woman, saying: "They shall be one flesh," and (one may add) one spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 32:39
verses.text: Wherefore Eve also believed the serpent; for she who had received the gift of good-will did not think there was ill-will.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:2
verses.text: Good-will exists especially in the Church, and nourishes kindred virtues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:4
verses.text: Good-will expands in the body of the Church, by fellowship in faith, by the bond of baptism, by kinship through grace received, by communion in the mysteries.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:5
verses.text: For all these bonds claim for themselves the name of intimacy, the reverence of children, the authority and religious care of parents, the relationship of brothers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:6
verses.text: Therefore the bonds of grace clearly point to an increase of good-will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:8
verses.text: The desire to attain to like virtues also stands one in good stead; just as again good-will brings about a likeness in character.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:9
verses.text: For Jonathan the king's son imitated the gentleness of holy David, because he loved him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:10
verses.text: Wherefore those words: "With the holy thou shalt be holy," seem not only to be concerned with our ordinary intercourse, but also to have some connection with good-will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:11
verses.text: The sons of Noah indeed dwelt together, and yet their characters were not at all alike.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:12
verses.text: Esau and Jacob also dwelt together in their father's house, but were very unlike.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:13
verses.text: There was, however, no good-will between them to make the one prefer the other to himself, but rather a rivalry as to which should first get the blessing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:14
verses.text: Since one was so hard, and the other gentle, good-will could not exist as between such different characters and conflicting desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:15
verses.text: Add to this the fact that holy Jacob could not prefer the unworthy in son of his father's house to virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:17
verses.text: But nothing is so harmonious as justice and impartiality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:18
verses.text: For this, as the comrade and ally of good-will, makes us love those whom we think to be like ourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:19
verses.text: Again, good-will contains also in itself fortitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:20
verses.text: For when friendship springs from the fount of good-will it does not hesitate to endure the great dangers of life for a friend.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 33:21
verses.text: "If evils come to me through him," it says, "I will bear them".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:2
verses.text: Some other advantages of goodwill are here enumerated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:4
verses.text: Good-will also is wont to remove the sword of anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:5
verses.text: It is also good-will that makes the wounds of a friend to be better than the willing kisses of an enemy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:6
verses.text: Goodwill again makes many to become one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:7
verses.text: For if many are friends, they become one; in whom there is but one spirit and one opinion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:8
verses.text: We note, too, that in friendship corrections are pleasing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:9
verses.text: They have their sting, but they cause no pain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:10
verses.text: We are pierced by the words of blame, but are delighted with the anxiety that good-will shows.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:12
verses.text: To conclude, the same duties are not owed to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:13
verses.text: Nor is regard ever paid to persons, though the occasion and the circumstances of the case are generally taken into consideration, so that one may at times have to help a neighbour rather than one's brother.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:14
verses.text: For Solomon also says: "Better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far  off".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:15
verses.text: For this reason a man generally trusts himself to the good-will of a friend rather than to the ties of relationship with his brother.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 34:16
verses.text: So far does good-will prevail that it often goes beyond the pledges given by nature.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:2
verses.text: On fortitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:3
verses.text: This is divided into two parts: as it concerns matters of war and matters at home.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:4
verses.text: The first cannot be a virtue unless combined with justice and prudence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:5
verses.text: The other depends to a large extent upon endurance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:7
verses.text: We have discussed fully enough the nature and force of what is virtuous from the standpoint of justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:8
verses.text: Now let us discuss fortitude, which (being a loftier virtue than the rest) is divided into two parts, as it concerns matters of war and matters at home.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:9
verses.text: But the thought of warlike matters seems to be foreign to the duty of our office, for we have our thoughts fixed more on the duty of the soul than on that of the body; nor is it our business to look to arms, but rather to the affairs of peace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:10
verses.text: Our fathers, however, as Joshua, the son of Nun, Jerubbaal, Samson, and David, gained great glory also in war.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:12
verses.text: Fortitude, therefore, is a loftier virtue than the rest, but it is also one that never stands alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:13
verses.text: For it never depends on itself alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:14
verses.text: Moreover, fortitude without justice is the source of wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:15
verses.text: For the stronger it is, the more ready is it to crush the weaker, whilst in matters of war one ought to see whether the war is just or unjust.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:17
verses.text: David never waged war unless he was driven to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:18
verses.text: Thus prudence was combined in him with fortitude in the battle.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:19
verses.text: For even when about to fight single-handed against Goliath, the enormous giant, he rejected the armour with which he was laden.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:20
verses.text: His strength depended more on his own arm than on the weapons of others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:21
verses.text: Then, at a distance, to get a stronger throw, with one cast of a stone, he slew his enemy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:22
verses.text: After that he never entered on a war without seeking counsel of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:23
verses.text: Thus he was victorious in all wars, and even to his last years was ready to fight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:24
verses.text: And when war arose with the Philistines, he joined battle with their fierce troops, being desirous of winning renown, whilst careless of his own safety.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:26
verses.text: But this is not the only kind of fortitude which is worthy of note.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:27
verses.text: We consider their fortitude glorious, who, with greatness of mind, "through faith stopped the mouth of lions, quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, out of weakness were made strong".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:28
verses.text: They did not gain a victory in common with many, surrounded with comrades, and aided by the legions, but won their triumph alone over their treacherous foes by the mere courage of their own souls.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:29
verses.text: How unconquerable was Daniel, who feared not the lions raging round about him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 35:30
verses.text: The beasts roared, whilst he was eating.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:2
verses.text: One of the duties of fortitude is to keep the weak from receiving injury; another, to check the wrong motions of our own souls; a third, both to disregard humiliations, and to do what is right with an even mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:3
verses.text: All these clearly ought to be fulfilled by all Christians, and especially by the clergy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:5
verses.text: The glory of fortitude, therefore, does not rest only on the strength of one's body or of one's arms, but rather on the courage of the mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:6
verses.text: Nor is the law of courage exercised in causing, but in driving away all harm.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:7
verses.text: He who does not keep harm off a friend, if he can, is as much in fault as he who causes it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:8
verses.text: Wherefore holy Moses gave this as a first proof of his fortitude in war.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:9
verses.text: For when he saw an Hebrew receiving hard treatment at the hands of an Egyptian, he defended him, and laid low the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:10
verses.text: Solomon also says: "Deliver him that is led to death".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:12
verses.text: From whence, then, Cicero and Panaetius, or even Aristotle, got these ideas is perfectly clear.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:13
verses.text: For though living before these two, Job had said: "I delivered the poor out of the hand of the strong, and I aided the fatherless for whom there was no helper.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:14
verses.text: Let the blessing of him that was ready to perish come upon me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:15
verses.text: Was not he most brave in that he bore so nobly the attacks of the devil, and overcame him with the powers of his mind? Nor have we cause to doubt the fortitude of him to whom the Lord said: "Gird up thy loins like a man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:16
verses.text: Put on loftiness and power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:17
verses.text: Humble every one that doeth wrong".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:18
verses.text: The Apostle  also says: "Ye have a strong consolation".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:19
verses.text: He, then, is brave who finds consolation in any grief.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:21
verses.text: And in very truth, rightly is that called fortitude, when a man conquers himself, restrains his anger, yields and gives way to no allurements, is not put out by misfortunes, nor gets elated by good success, and does not get carried away by every varying change as by some chance wind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:22
verses.text: But what is more noble and splendid than to train the mind, keep down the flesh, and reduce it to subjection, so that it may obey commands, listen to reason, and in undergoing labours readily carry out the intention and wish of the mind?  182.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:23
verses.text: This, then, is the first notion of fortitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:24
verses.text: For fortitude of the mind can be regarded in two ways.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:25
verses.text: First, as it counts all externals as very unimportant, and looks on them as rather superfluous and to be despised than to be sought after.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:26
verses.text: Secondly, as it strives after those things which are the highest, and all things in which one can see anything moral (or as the Greeks call it, πρέπον,) with all the powers of the mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:27
verses.text: For what can be more noble than to train thy mind so as not to place a high value on riches and pleasures and honours, nor to waste all thy care on these? When thy mind is thus disposed, thou must consider how all that is virtuous and seemly must be placed before everything else; and thou must so fix thy mind upon that, that if aught happens which may break thy spirit, whether loss of property, or the reception of fewer honours, or the disparagement of unbelievers, thou mayest not feel it, as though thou wert above such things; nay, so that even dangers which menace thy safety, if undertaken at the call of justice, may not trouble thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:28
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:29
verses.text: This is the true fortitude which Christ's warrior has, who receives not the crown unless he strives lawfully.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:30
verses.text: Or does that call to fortitude seem to thee but a poor one: "Tribulation worketh patience, and patience, experience, and experience, hope"? See how many a contest there is, yet but one crown! That call none gives, but he who was strengthened in Christ Jesus, and whose flesh had no rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:31
verses.text: Affliction on all sides, fighting without and fears within.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:32
verses.text: And though in dangers, in countless labours, in prisons, in deaths—he was not broken in spirit, but fought so as to become more powerful through his infirmities.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:33
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:34
verses.text: Think, then, how he teaches those who enter upon their duties in the Church, that they ought to have contempt for all earthly things: "If, then, ye be dead with Christ from the elements of this world, why do ye act as though living in the world? Touch not, taste not, handle not, which all are to perish with the using".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:35
verses.text: And further: "If ye then be risen with Christ, seek those things which are above, not those things which are on the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:36
verses.text: And again: "Mortify, therefore, your members which are on the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:37
verses.text: This, indeed, is meant for all the faithful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:38
verses.text: But thee, especially, my son, he urges to despise riches and to avoid profane and old wives fables—allowing nothing but this: "Exercise thyself unto godliness, for bodily exercise profiteth a little, but godliness is profitable unto all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:39
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:40
verses.text: Let, then, godliness exercise thee unto justice, continence, gentleness, that thou mayest avoid childish acts, and that rooted and grounded in grace thou mayest fight the good fight of faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:41
verses.text: Entangle not thyself in the affairs of this life, for thou art fighting for God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:42
verses.text: For if he who fights for the emperor is forbidden by human laws to enter upon lawsuits, to do any legal business, or to sell merchandise; how much more ought he who enters upon the warfare of faith to keep from every kind of business, being satisfied with the produce of his own little bit of land, if he has it? If he has not that, let him be content with the pay he will get for his service.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:43
verses.text: Here is a good witness to this fact, who says: "I have been young and now am old, yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 36:44
verses.text: That is the true rest and temperance of the mind which is not excited by the desire of gain, nor tormented by the fear of want.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:2
verses.text: An even mind should be preserved in adversity as well as in prosperity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:3
verses.text: However, evil things must be avoided.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:5
verses.text: There is also that true freedom of the mind from vexation which makes us neither give way too much in our griefs, nor be too elated in prosperity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:6
verses.text: And if they who urge men to undertake the affairs of the state give such rules, how much more  ought we who are called to do duty in the Church, to act thus and do those things which are pleasing to God, so that Christ's power may show itself forth in us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:7
verses.text: We too must prove ourselves to our Captain, so that our members may be the weapons of justice; not carnal weapons in which sin may reign, but weapons strong for God, whereby sin may be destroyed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:8
verses.text: Let our flesh die, that in it every sin may die.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:9
verses.text: And as though living again after death, may we rise to new works and a new life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:11
verses.text: These, then, are the services of fortitude; and full they are of virtuous and seemly duties.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:12
verses.text: But in all that we do we must look to see, not only if it is virtuous, but whether it is possible, so that we may not enter upon anything that we cannot carry out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 37:13
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord, to use His own word, wills us to flee in the time of persecution from one city to another; so that no one, whilst longing for the crown of martyrdom, may put himself in the way of dangers which possibly the weak flesh or a mind indulged could not bear and endure.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:2
verses.text: We must strengthen the mind against troubles to come, and build it up by looking out for them beforehand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:3
verses.text: What difficulties there are in doing this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:5
verses.text: But again, no one must retire through cowardice, or give up his faith from fear of danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:6
verses.text: With what grace must the soul be equipped, and the mind trained and taught to stand firm, so as never to be disturbed by any fears, to be broken by any troubles, or to yield to any torments! With what difficulty indeed are they borne! But as all pains seem less in the fear of greater pains, so also, if thou dost build up thy soul by quiet counsel, and dost determine not to go from thy course, and layest before thee the fear of divine judgment and the torment of eternal punishment, canst thou gain endurance of mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:8
verses.text: If a man thus prepares himself, he gives signs of great diligence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:9
verses.text: On the other hand it is a sign of natural ability, if a man by the power of his mind can foresee the future, and put as it were before his eyes what may happen, and decide what he ought to do if it should take place.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:10
verses.text: It may happen, too, that he will think over two or three things at once, which he supposes may come either singly or together, and that he settles what he will do with them as he thinks will be to the most advantage, in the event of their coming either singly or together.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:12
verses.text: Therefore it is the duty of a brave man not to shut his eyes when anything threatens, but to put it before him and to search it out as it were in the mirror of his mind, and to meet the future with foreseeing thought, for fear he might afterwards have to say: This has come to me because I thought it could not come about.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:13
verses.text: If misfortunes are not looked for beforehand, they quickly get a hold over us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:14
verses.text: In war an unexpected enemy is with difficulty resisted, and if he finds the others unprepared, he easily overcomes them; so evils unthought of readily break down the soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:16
verses.text: In these two points, then, consists the excellency of the soul: so that thy soul, trained in good thoughts, and with a pure heart, first, may see what is true and virtuous (for "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God"), and may decide that only to be good which is virtuous; and, next, may never be disturbed by business of any kind, nor get tossed about by any desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:18
verses.text: Not that this is an easy thing for any one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:19
verses.text: For what is so difficult as to discern, as though from some watch-tower, the resources of wisdom and all those other things, which to most seem so great and noble? Again, what so difficult as to place one's decision on fixed grounds, and to despise what one has decided to be worthless, as of no good? Or, once more, what so difficult, when some misfortune has happened, and it is looked on as something serious and grieving, as to bear it in such a way that one considers it nothing beyond what is natural, when one reads: "Naked was I born, naked shall I go forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:20
verses.text: What the Lord gave, the Lord hath taken away" (he who said this had lost children and possessions), and to preserve in all things the character of a wise and upright man, as he did who says: "As the Lord pleased, so did He.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:21
verses.text: Blessed be the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:22
verses.text: And again: "Thou speakest as one of the foolish women speaketh.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 38:23
verses.text: Shall we receive good at the hand of God, and shall we not receive evil?".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:2
verses.text: One must show fortitude in fighting against all vices, especially against avarice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:3
verses.text: Holy Job teaches this lesson.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:5
verses.text: Fortitude of soul, then, is not an unimportant thing, nor is it cut off from the other virtues, for it wages war in conjunction with the virtues, and alone defends the beauty of all the virtues, and guards their powers of discernment, and fights against all vices with implacable hate.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:6
verses.text: It is unconquerable as regards labours, brave to endure dangers, stern as against pleasures, hardened against allurements, to which it knows not how to lend an ear, nor, so to speak, to give a greeting.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:7
verses.text: It cares not for money, and flies from avarice as from a plague that destroys all virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:8
verses.text: For nothing is so much opposed to fortitude as when one allows oneself to be overcome by gain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:9
verses.text: Often when the enemy is repulsed and the hosts of the foe are turned to flight, has the warrior died miserably among those whom he has laid low, whilst he is busy with the spoils of the fallen; and the legions, whilst busy with their booty, have called back upon them the enemy that had fled, and so have been robbed of their triumph.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:11
verses.text: Fortitude, then, must repulse so foul a plague and crush it down.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:12
verses.text: It must not let itself be tempted by desires, nor shaken by fear.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:13
verses.text: Virtue stands true to itself and bravely pursues all vices as though they were the poison of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:14
verses.text: It must repel anger as it were with arms, for it removes counsel far off.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:15
verses.text: It must avoid it as though it were some severe sickness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:16
verses.text: It must further be on its guard against a desire for glory, which often has done harm when sought for too anxiously, and always when it has been once attained.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:18
verses.text: What of all this was wanting in holy Job, or in his virtue, or what came upon him in the way of vice? How did he bear the distress of sickness or cold or hunger? How did he look upon the dangers which menaced his safety? Were the riches from which so much went to the poor gathered together by plunder? Did he ever allow greed for wealth, or the desire for pleasures, or lusts to rise in his heart? Did ever the unkind disputes of the three princes, or the insults of the slaves, rouse him to anger? Did glory carry him away like some fickle person when he called down vengeance on himself if ever he had hidden even an involuntary fault, or had feared the multitude of the people so as not to confess it in the sight of all? His virtues had no point of contact with any vices, but stood firm on their own ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 39:19
verses.text: Who, then, was so brave as holy Job? How can he be put second to any, on whose level hardly one like himself can be placed?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:1
verses.text: Chapter XL.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:2
verses.text: Courage in war was not wanting in our forefathers, as is shown by the example of the men of old, especially by the glorious deed of Eleazar.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:4
verses.text: But perhaps renown in war keeps some so bound to itself as to make them think that fortitude is to be found in battle alone, and that therefore I had gone aside to speak of these things, because that was wanting in us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:5
verses.text: But how brave was Joshua the son of Nun, who in one battle laid low five kings together with their people! Again, when he fought against the Gibeonites and feared that night might stop him from gaining the victory, he called out with deep faith and high spirit: "Let the sun stand still;" and it stood still until the victory was complete.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:6
verses.text: Gideon with three hundred men gained a triumph over a great nation and a cruel foe.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:7
verses.text: Jonathan when a young man showed great courage in battle, and what shall I say about the Maccabees?  206.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:8
verses.text: First, I will speak of the people of our fathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:9
verses.text: They were ready to fight for the temple of God and for their rights, and when attacked on the Sabbath day by the craft of the enemy, willingly allowed wounds to be inflicted on their unprotected bodies, rather than to join in the fight, so that they might not defile the Sabbath.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:10
verses.text: They all gladly gave themselves up to death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:11
