verses.text: But the Maccabees thinking that then all the nation would perish, on the Sabbath also, when they were challenged to fight, took vengeance for the death of their innocent brethren.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:12
verses.text: And afterwards when he had been roused by this to fresh exertions, King Antiochus, having begun the war afresh under the leadership of his generals Lysias, Nicanor, and Georgias, was so utterly crushed, together with his Eastern and Assyrian forces, that he left 48,000 lying on the battle-field, slain by an army of but 3,000 men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:14
verses.text: Mark the courage of the leader, Judas Maccabaeus, as exemplified in the character of one of his soldiers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:15
verses.text: Eleazar, meeting with an elephant higher than all the rest, and with all the royal trappings upon it, and thinking that the king was on it, ran hastily and threw himself into the midst of the legion; and, casting away his shield, with both hands he slew those opposed to him until he reached the beast.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:16
verses.text: Then he got beneath it, thrust in his sword and slew it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:17
verses.text: But the beast in falling crushed Eleazar and so killed him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:18
verses.text: What courage of mind was his then, first, in that he feared not death, next because, when surrounded by enemies, he was carried by it into the thickest of his foes and penetrated the very centre! Then, despising death, and casting away his shield, he ran beneath the huge beast, wounded it with both his hands, and let it fall upon him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:19
verses.text: He ran beneath it so as to give a more deadly blow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:20
verses.text: Enclosed by its fall, rather than crushed, he was buried in his own triumph.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:22
verses.text: Nor was he deceived in his intention though he was deceived by the royal ornaments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:23
verses.text: For the enemy, startled at such an exhibition of valour, dared not rush upon this single unarmed man, held fast though he was.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:24
verses.text: They were so terrified after the mischance of the slaughter of the beast, that they considered themselves altogether unequal to the valour of one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:25
verses.text: Nay, King Antiochus, son of Lysias, terrified at the fortitude of one, asked for peace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:26
verses.text: He had come to the war with 120,000 armed men and with 32 elephants, which glittered and gleamed with the sheen of arms like a line of burning lamps, as the sun rose upon them, marching along one by one, like very mountains for size.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:27
verses.text: Thus Eleazar left peace as the heir of his courage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 40:28
verses.text: These are the signs of triumphs.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:1
verses.text: Chapter XLI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:2
verses.text: After praising Judas' and Jonathan's loftiness of mind, the constancy of the martyrs in their endurance of tortures, which is no small part of fortitude, is next brought before us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:4
verses.text: But as fortitude is proved not only by prosperity but also in adversity, let us now consider the death of Judas Maccabaeus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:5
verses.text: For he, after Nicanor, the general of King Demetrius, was defeated, boldly engaged 20,000 of the king's army with 900 men who were anxious to retire for fear of being overcome by so great a multitude, but whom he persuaded to endure a glorious death rather than to retire in disgraceful flight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:6
verses.text: "Let us not leave," he says, "any stain upon our glory".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:7
verses.text: Thus, then, engaging in battle after having fought from sunrise till evening, he attacks and quickly drives back the right wing, where he sees the strongest troop of the enemy to be.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:8
verses.text: But whilst pursuing the fugitives from the rear he gave a chance for a wound to be inflicted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:9
verses.text: Thus he found the spot of death more full of glory for himself than any triumph.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:11
verses.text: Why need I further mention his brother Jonathan, who fought against the king's force, with but a small troop.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:12
verses.text: Though forsaken by his men, and left with only two, he retrieved the battle, drove back the enemy, and recalled his own men, who were flying in every direction, to share in his triumph.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:14
verses.text: Here, then, is fortitude in war, which bears no light impress of what is virtuous and seemly upon it, for it prefers death to slavery and disgrace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:15
verses.text: But what am I to say of the sufferings of the martyrs? Not to go too far abroad, did not the children of Maccabaeus gain triumphs over the proud King Antiochus, as great as those of their fathers? The latter in truth were armed, but they conquered without arms.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:16
verses.text: The company of the seven brothers stood unconquered, though surrounded by the legions of the king—tortures failed, tormentors ceased; but the martyrs failed not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:17
verses.text: One, having had the skin of his head pulled off, though changed in appearance, grew in courage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:18
verses.text: Another, bidden to put forth his tongue, so that it might be cut off, answered: "The Lord hears not only those who speak, for He heard Moses when silent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:19
verses.text: He hears better the silent thoughts of His own than the voice of all others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:20
verses.text: Dost thou fear the scourge of my tongue—and dost thou not fear the scourge of blood spilt upon the ground? Blood, too, has a voice whereby it cries aloud to God—as it did in the case of Abel".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:22
verses.text: What shall I say of the mother who with joy looked on the corpses of her children as so many trophies, and found delight in the voices of her dying sons, as though in the songs of singers, noting in her children the tones of the glorious harp  of her own heart, and a sweeter harmony of love than any strain of the lute could give?  213.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:23
verses.text: What shall I say of those two-year-old children of Bethlehem, who received the palm of victory before they felt their natural life within them? What of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:24
verses.text: Agnes, who when in danger as regards two great matters, that is, chastity and life, protected her chastity and exchanged life for immortality?  214.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:25
verses.text: And let us not pass by St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:26
verses.text: Lawrence, who, seeing Xystus his bishop led to martyrdom, began to weep, not at his sufferings but at the fact that he himself was to remain behind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:27
verses.text: With these words he began to address him: "Whither, father, goest thou without thy son? Whither, holy priest, art thou hastening without thy deacon? Never wast thou wont to offer sacrifice without an attendant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:28
verses.text: What are thou displeased at in me, my father? Hast thou found me unworthy? Prove, then, whether thou hast chosen a fitting servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:29
verses.text: To him to whom thou hast entrusted the consecration of the Saviour's blood, to whom thou hast granted fellowship in partaking of the Sacraments, to him dost thou refuse a part in thy death? Beware lest thy good judgment be endangered, whilst thy fortitude receives its praise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:30
verses.text: The rejection of a pupil is the loss of the teacher; or how is it that noble and illustrious men gain the victory in the contests of their scholars rather than in their own? Abraham offered his son, Peter sent Stephen on before him! Do thou, father, show forth thy courage in thy son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:31
verses.text: Offer me whom thou hast trained, that thou, confident in thy choice of me, mayest reach the crown in worthy company".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:33
verses.text: Then Xystus said: "I leave thee not nor forsake thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:34
verses.text: Greater struggles yet await thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:35
verses.text: We as old men have to undergo an easier fight; a more glorious triumph over the tyrant awaits thee, a young man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:36
verses.text: Soon shalt thou come.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:37
verses.text: Cease weeping; after three days thou shalt follow me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:38
verses.text: This interval must come between the priest and his levite.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:39
verses.text: It was not for thee to conquer under the eye of thy master, as though thou neededst a helper.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:40
verses.text: Why dost thou seek to share in my death? I leave to thee its full inheritance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:41
verses.text: Why dost thou need my presence? Let the weak disciples go before their master, let the brave follow him, that they may conquer without him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:42
verses.text: For they no longer need his guidance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:43
verses.text: So Elijah left Elisha.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:44
verses.text: To thee I entrust the full succession to my own courage".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:45
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:46
verses.text: Such was their contention, and surely a worthy one, wherein priest and attendant strove as to who should be the first to suffer for the name of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:47
verses.text: When that tragic piece is played, it is said there is great applause in the theatre as Pylades says he is Orestes, whilst Orestes declares that he is really himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:48
verses.text: The former acted as he did, that he might die for Orestes, and Orestes, that he might not allow Pylades to be slain instead of himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:49
verses.text: But it was not right that they should live, for each of them was guilty of parricide, the one because he had committed the crime, the other because he had helped in its commission.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:50
verses.text: But here there was nothing to call holy Lawrence to act thus but his love and devotion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:51
verses.text: However, after three days he was placed upon the gridiron by the tyrant whom he mocked, and was burnt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:52
verses.text: He said: "The flesh is roasted, turn it and eat".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 41:53
verses.text: So by the courage of his mind he overcame the power of fire.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:1
verses.text: Chapter XLII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:2
verses.text: The powers that be are not needlessly to be irritated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:3
verses.text: One must not lend one's ears to flattery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:5
verses.text: I think we must take care, lest in being led on by too great a desire for glory, we should abuse the powers that be, and arouse the minds of the heathen, who are opposed to us, to desire persecution, and excite them to anger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:6
verses.text: How many do some cause to perish, that they themselves may continue to the end, and overcome their tortures!  218.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:7
verses.text: We must also look to it that we do not open our ears to flatterers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 42:8
verses.text: To allow oneself to be smoothed down by flattery seems to be a sign not only of want of fortitude, but a sign of actual cowardice.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:2
verses.text: On temperance and its chief parts, especially tranquillity of mind and moderation, care for what is virtuous, and reflection on what is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:4
verses.text: As we have spoken of three of the virtues, there remains but the fourth for us to speak of.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:5
verses.text: This is called temperance and  moderation; wherein, before all else, tranquillity of mind, the attainment of gentleness, the grace of moderation, regard for what is virtuous, and reflection on what is seemly are sought and looked for.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:7
verses.text: We must keep to a certain order in life, so that a foundation may be laid with our first feelings of modesty, for that is the friend and ally of calmness of mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:8
verses.text: Avoiding over-confidence, averse to all excess, it loves sobriety, guards what is honourable, and seeks only what is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:10
verses.text: Let choice of intercourse come next.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:11
verses.text: Let us link ourselves with older men of approved goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:12
verses.text: For as the companionship of people of our own age is the pleasanter, so that of our elders is the safer.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:13
verses.text: By their guidance and the conduct of their lives they give colour to the character of younger men, and tinge them as it were with the deep purple of probity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:14
verses.text: For if they who are ignorant of a locality are very glad to take a journey in the company of skilled guides, how much more ought young men to enter on the path of life, which is new to them, in the company of old men; so that they may not go wrong, and turn aside from the true path of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:15
verses.text: For nothing is better than to have the same men both to direct us in life, and also to be witnesses of how we live.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:17
verses.text: One must also in every action consider what is suitable for different persons, times, and ages, and what will also be in accordance with the abilities of individuals.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:18
verses.text: For often what befits one does not befit another; one thing suits a youth, another an old man; one thing does in danger, another in good fortune.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:20
verses.text: David danced before the ark of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:21
verses.text: Samuel did not dance; yet David was not blamed, while the other was praised.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:22
verses.text: David changed his countenance before the king, whose name was Achish.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:23
verses.text: If he had done this without any fear of being recognized, he would certainly not have escaped the charge of levity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:24
verses.text: Saul also, surrounded by the company of prophets, himself prophesied.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 43:25
verses.text: Yet of him alone, as though he were unworthy, was it said: "Is Saul also among the prophets?".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:2
verses.text: Every one ought to apply himself to the duties suited to his character.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:3
verses.text: Many, however, are hindered by following their fathers' pursuits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:4
verses.text: Clerics act in a different way.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:6
verses.text: Each one knows his own powers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:7
verses.text: Therefore let each one apply himself to that which he has chosen as suitable to himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:8
verses.text: But he must first consider what will be the consequences.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:9
verses.text: He may know his good points, but he must know his faults also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:10
verses.text: He must also be a fair judge of himself, so as to aim at what is good and avoid what is bad.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:12
verses.text: One is more fitted for the post of reader, another does better for the singing, a third is more solicitous for exorcising those possessed with an evil spirit, another, again, is held to be more suited to have the charge of the sacred things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:13
verses.text: All these things a priest should look at.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:14
verses.text: He should give each one that particular duty for which he is best fitted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:15
verses.text: For whither each one's bent of mind leads him, or whatever duty befits him, that position or duty is filled with greater grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:17
verses.text: But as this is a difficult matter in every state of life, so in our case it is most difficult.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:18
verses.text: For each one is wont to follow his parent's choice in life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:19
verses.text: Thus those whose fathers were in the army generally enter the army too.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:20
verses.text: And others do the same with regard to the different professions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:22
verses.text: In the clerical office, however, nothing is more rare than to find a man to follow his father's footsteps, either because the difficulties of the work hold him back, or continence in the uncertain days of youth is too difficult to hold to, or the life seems to be too quiet for the activity of youth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:23
verses.text: So they turn to those pursuits which are thought to be more showy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:24
verses.text: Most, indeed, prefer the present to the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:25
verses.text: They are fighting for the present, we for the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 44:26
verses.text: Wherefore it follows that the greater the cause in which we are engaged, the more must our attention be devoted to it.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:1
verses.text: Chapter XLV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:2
verses.text: On what is noble and virtuous, and what the difference between them is, as stated both in the profane and sacred writers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:4
verses.text: Let us then hold fast modesty, and that moderation which adds to the beauty of the whole of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:5
verses.text: For it is no light thing in every matter to preserve due measure  and to bring about order, wherein that is plainly conspicuous which we call "decorum," or what is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:6
verses.text: This is so closely connected with what is virtuous, that one cannot separate the two.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:7
verses.text: For what is seemly is also virtuous—and what is virtuous is seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:8
verses.text: So that the distinction lies rather in the words than in the things themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:9
verses.text: That there is a difference between them we can understand, but we cannot explain it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:11
verses.text: To make an attempt to get some sort of a distinction between them, we may say that what is virtuous may be compared to the good health and soundness of the body, whilst what is seemly is, as it were, its comeliness and beauty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:12
verses.text: And as beauty seems to stand above soundness and health, and yet cannot exist without them, nor be separated from them in any way—for unless one has good health, one cannot have beauty and comeliness—so what is virtuous contains in itself also what is seemly, so as to seem to start with it, and to be unable to exist without it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:13
verses.text: What is virtuous, then, is like soundness in all our work and undertaking; what is seemly is, as it were, the outward appearance, which, when joined with what is virtuous, can only be known apart in our thoughts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:14
verses.text: For though in some cases it seems to stand out conspicuous, yet it has its root in what is virtuous, though the flower is its own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:15
verses.text: Rooted in this, it flourishes; otherwise it fails and droops.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:16
verses.text: For what is virtue, but to avoid anything shameful as though it were death? And what is the opposite of virtue, except that which brings barrenness and death? If, then, the essence of virtue is strong and vigorous, seemliness will also quickly spring forth like a flower, for its root is sound.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:17
verses.text: But if the root of its purpose is corrupt, nothing will grow out of it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:19
verses.text: In our writings this is put somewhat more plainly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:20
verses.text: For David says: "The Lord reigneth, He is clothed with splendour".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:21
verses.text: And the Apostle says: "Walk honestly as in the day".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:22
verses.text: The Greek text has ευσχημόνως —and this really means: with good clothing, with a good appearance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:23
verses.text: When God made the first man, He created him with a good figure, with limbs well set, and gave him a very noble appearance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:24
verses.text: He had not given him remission of sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:25
verses.text: But afterwards He, Who came in the form of a servant, and in the likeness of man, renewed him with His Spirit, and poured His grace into his heart, and put on Himself the splendour of the redemption of the human race.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:26
verses.text: Therefore the Prophet said: "The Lord reigneth, He is clothed with splendour".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:27
verses.text: And again he says: "A hymn beseems Thee, O God, in Sion".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:28
verses.text: That is: It is right and good to fear Thee, to love Thee, to pray to Thee, to honour Thee, for it is written: "Let all things be done decently and in order".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:29
verses.text: But we can also fear, love, ask, honour men; yet the hymn especially is addressed to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:30
verses.text: This seemliness which we offer to God we may believe to be far better than other things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 45:31
verses.text: It befits also a woman to pray in an orderly dress, but it especially beseems her to pray covered, and to pray giving promise of purity together with a good conversation.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:2
verses.text: A twofold division of what is seemly is given.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:3
verses.text: Next it is shown that what is according to nature is virtuous, and what is otherwise must be looked on as shameful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:4
verses.text: This division is explained by examples.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:6
verses.text: Seemliness, therefore, which stands conspicuous has a twofold division.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:7
verses.text: For there is what we may call a general seemliness, which is diffused through all that is virtuous, and is seen, as one may say, in the whole body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:8
verses.text: It is also individual, and shows itself clearly in some particular part.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:9
verses.text: The first has a consistent form and the perfection of what is virtuous harmonizing in every action.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:10
verses.text: For all its life is consistent with itself, and there is no discrepancy in anything.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:11
verses.text: The other is concerned when there is any special action done in a virtuous course of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:13
verses.text: At the same time let us note that it is seemly to live in accordance with nature, and to pass our time in accordance with it, and that whatever is contrary to nature is shameful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:14
verses.text: For the Apostle asks: "Is it comely that a woman pray unto God uncovered; doth not nature itself teach you that if a man have long hair, it is a shame unto him? For it is contrary to nature".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:15
verses.text: And again he says: "If a woman have long hair, it is a glory unto her".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:16
verses.text: It is according to nature, since her hair is given her for a veil, for it is a natural veil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:17
verses.text: Thus nature arranges for us both character and  appearance, and we ought to observe her directions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:18
verses.text: Would that we could guard her innocence, and not change what we have received by our wickedness!  233.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:19
verses.text: We have that general seemliness; for God made the beauty of this world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:20
verses.text: We have it also in its parts; for when God made the light, and marked off the day from the night, when He made heaven, and separated land and seas, when He set the sun and moon and stars to shine on the earth, He approved of them all one by one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:21
verses.text: Therefore this comeliness, which shone forth in each single part of the world, was resplendent in the whole, as the Book of Wisdom shows, saying: "I existed, in whom He rejoiced when He was glad at the completion of the world".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:22
verses.text: Likewise also in the building up of the human body each single member is pleasing, but the right adjustment of the members all together delights us far more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 46:23
verses.text: For thus they seem to be united and fitted in one harmonious whole.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:2
verses.text: What is seemly should always shine forth in our life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:3
verses.text: What passions, then, ought we to allow to come to a head, and which should we restrain?  234.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:4
verses.text: If any one preserves an even tenor in the whole of life, and method in all that he does, and sees there is order and consistency in his words and moderation in his deeds, then what is seemly stands forth conspicuous in his life and shines forth as in some mirror.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:6
verses.text: There should be besides a pleasant way of speaking, so that we may win the good-will of those who hear us, and make ourselves agreeable to all our friends and fellow-citizens, if possible.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:7
verses.text: Let none show himself to be given to flattery, nor to be desirous of flattery from any one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:8
verses.text: The one is a mark of artfulness, the other of vanity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:10
verses.text: Let no one ever look down on what another, least of all a good man, thinks of him, for thus he learns to give regard to the good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:11
verses.text: For to disregard the judgment of good men is a sign of conceitedness or of weakness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:12
verses.text: One of these arises from pride, the other from carelessness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:14
verses.text: We must also guard against the motions of our soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:15
verses.text: The soul must always watch and look after itself, so as to guard itself against itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:16
verses.text: For there are motions in which there is a kind of passion that breaks forth as it were in a sort of rush.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:17
verses.text: Wherefore in Greek it is called ὁρμή, because it comes out suddenly with some force.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:18
verses.text: In these there lies no slight force of soul or of nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:19
verses.text: Its force, however, is twofold: on the one side it rests on passion, on the other on reason, which checks passion, and makes it obedient to itself, and leads it whither it will; and trains it by careful teaching to know what ought to be done, and what ought to be avoided, so as to make it submit to its kind tamer.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:21
verses.text: For we ought to be careful never to do anything rashly or carelessly, or anything at all for which we cannot give a reasonable ground.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:22
verses.text: For though a reason for our action is not given to every one, yet everybody looks into it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:23
verses.text: Nor, indeed, have we anything whereby we can excuse ourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:24
verses.text: For though there is a sort of natural force in every passion of ours, yet that same passion is subject to reason by the law of nature itself, and is obedient to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:25
verses.text: Wherefore it is the duty of a careful watchman so to keep a lookout, that passion may not outrun reason nor utterly forsake it, lest by outstripping it confusion be caused, and reason be shut out, and come to nothing by such desertion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:26
verses.text: Disquiet destroys consistency.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:27
verses.text: Withdrawal shows cowardice and implies indolence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:28
verses.text: For when the mind is disquieted passion spreads wide and far, and in a fierce outburst endures not the reins of reason and feels not the management of its driver so as to be turned back.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:29
verses.text: Wherefore as a rule not only is the soul perturbed and reason lost, but one's countenance gets inflamed by anger or by lust.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:30
verses.text: it grows pale with fear, it contains not itself in pleasure, and cannot bear joy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:32
verses.text: When this happens, then that natural judgment and weight of character is cast aside, and that consistency which alone in deed and thought can keep up its own authority and what is seemly, can no longer be retained.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:33
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:34
verses.text: But fiercer passion springs from excessive anger, which the pain of some wrong received kindles within us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:35
verses.text: The monitions of the psalm which forms the opening of our subject instruct us on this point.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:36
verses.text: Beautifully, then, has it come about that, in writing on duties, we used that declaration of our opening passage which also itself has to do with the direction of duty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:37
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:38
verses.text: But since (as was but right) we there only touched upon the matter, as to how  each one ought to take care not to be disturbed when wrong is done him, for fear that our preliminary remarks should run to too great length, I think that I will now discuss it a little more fully.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 47:39
verses.text: For the occasion is opportune, as we are speaking on the different parts of temperance, to see how anger may be checked.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:2
verses.text: The argument for restraining anger is given again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:3
verses.text: Then the three classes of those who receive wrongs are set forth; to the most perfect of which the Apostle and David are said to have attained.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:4
verses.text: He takes the opportunity to state the difference between this and the future life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:6
verses.text: We wish if we can to point out three classes of men who receive wrongs in holy Scripture.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:7
verses.text: One of these forms the class of those whom the sinner reviles, abuses, rides over rough-shod.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:8
verses.text: And just because justice fails them, shame grows, pain increases.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:9
verses.text: Very many of my own order, of my own number, are like these.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:10
verses.text: For if any one does me, who am weak, an injury, perhaps, though I am weak, I may forgive the wrong done me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:11
verses.text: If he charges me with an offence I am not such an one as to be content with the witness of my own conscience, although I know I am clear of what he brings against me; but I desire, just because I am weak, to wash out the mark of my inborn shame.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:12
verses.text: Therefore I demand eye for eye, and tooth for tooth, and repay abuse with abuse.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:14
verses.text: If, however, I am one who is advancing, although not yet perfect, I do not return the reproaches; and if he breaks out into abuse, and fills my ears with reproaches, I am silent and do not answer.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:16
verses.text: But if I am perfect (I say this only by way of example, for in truth I am weak), if, then, I am perfect, I bless him that curses me, as Paul also blessed, for he says: "Being reviled we bless".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:17
verses.text: He had heard Him Who says: "Love your enemies, pray for them which despitefully use you and persecute you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:18
verses.text: And so Paul suffered persecution and endured it, for he conquered and calmed his human feelings for the sake of the reward set before him, namely, that he should become a son of God if he loved his enemies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:20
verses.text: We call show, too, that holy David was like to Paul in this same class of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:21
verses.text: When the son of Shimei cursed him, and charged him with heavy offences, at the first he was silent and humbled himself, and was silent even about his good deeds, that is, his knowledge of good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:22
verses.text: Then he even asked to be cursed; for when he was cursed he hoped to gain divine pity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:24
verses.text: But see how he stored up humility and justice and prudence so as to merit grace from the Lord! At first he said: "Therefore he cursed me, because the Lord hath said unto him that he should curse".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:25
verses.text: Here we have humility; for he thought that those things which are divinely ordered were to be endured with an even mind, as though he were but some servant lad.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:26
verses.text: Then he said: "Behold my son, which came forth of my bowels, seeketh my life".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:27
verses.text: Here we have justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:28
verses.text: For if we suffer hard things at the hand of our own family, why are we angry at what is done to us by strangers? Lastly he says: "Let him alone that he may curse, for the Lord hath bidden him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:29
verses.text: It may be that the Lord will look on my humiliation and requite me good for this cursing".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:30
verses.text: So he bore not only the abuse, but left the man unpunished when throwing stones and following him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:31
verses.text: Nay, more, after his victory he freely granted him pardon when he asked for it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:33
verses.text: I have written this to show that holy David, in true evangelical spirit, was not only not offended, but was even thankful to his abuser, and was delighted rather than angered by his wrongs, for which he thought some return would be granted to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:34
verses.text: But, though perfect, he sought something still more perfect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:35
verses.text: As a man he grew hot at the pain of his wrongs, but like a good soldier he conquered, he endured like a brave wrestler.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:36
verses.text: The end and aim of his patience was the expectation of the fulfilment of the promises, and therefore he said: "Lord, make me to know mine end and the measure of my days, what it is: that I may know what is wanting to me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:37
verses.text: He seeks, then, that end of the heavenly promises, when each one shall arise in his own order: "Christ the firstfruits, then they that are Christ's who have believed in His coming.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:38
verses.text: Then cometh the end".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:39
verses.text: For when the kingdom is delivered up to God, even the Father, and all the powers are put down, as the Apostle says, then perfection begins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:40
verses.text: Here, then, is the hindrance, here the weakness of the perfect; there full perfection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:41
verses.text: Thus it is he asks for those days of eternal life which are, and not for those which pass away, so that he may know what is wanting to  him, what is the land of promise that bears everlasting fruits, which is the first mansion in his Father's house, which the second, which the third, wherein each one will rest according to his merits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:42
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:43
verses.text: We then must strive for that wherein is perfection and wherein is truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:44
verses.text: Here is the shadow, here the image; there the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:45
verses.text: The shadow is in the law, the image in the Gospel, the truth in heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:46
verses.text: In old times a lamb, a Calf was offered; now Christ is offered.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:47
verses.text: But He is offered as man and as enduring suffering.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:48
verses.text: And He offers Himself as a priest to take away our sins, here in an image, there in truth, where with the Father He intercedes for us as our Advocate.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:49
verses.text: Here, then, we walk in an image, we see in an image; there face to face where is full perfection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 48:50
verses.text: For all perfection rests in the truth.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:2
verses.text: We must reserve the likeness of the virtues in ourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:3
verses.text: The likeness of the devil and of vice must be got rid of, and especially that of avarice; for this deprives us of liberty, and despoils those who are in the midst of vanities of the image of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:5
verses.text: Whilst, then, we are here let us preserve the likeness, that there we may attain to the truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:6
verses.text: Let the likeness of justice exist in us, likewise that of wisdom, for we shall come to that day and shall be rewarded according to our likeness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:8
verses.text: Let not the adversary find his image in thee, let him not find fury nor rage; for in these exists the likeness of wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:9
verses.text: "Our adversary the devil as a roaring lion seeketh whom he may kill, whom he may devour".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:10
verses.text: Let him not find desire for gold, nor heaps of money, nor the appearance of vices, lest he take from thee the voice of liberty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:11
verses.text: For the voice of true liberty is heard, when thou canst say: "The prince of this world shall come, and shall find no part in me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:12
verses.text: Therefore, if thou art sure that he will find nothing in thee, when he comes to search through thee, thou wilt say, as the patriarch Jacob did to Laban: "Know now if there is aught of thine with me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:13
verses.text: Rightly do we account Jacob blessed with whom Laban could find naught of his.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:14
verses.text: For Rachel had hidden the gold and silver images of his gods.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:16
verses.text: If, then, wisdom, and faith, and contempt of the world, and spiritual grace, exclude all faithlessness, thou wilt be blessed; for thou regardest not vanity and folly and lying.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:17
verses.text: Is it a light thing to take away from thy adversary the opportunity to speak, so that he can have no ground to make his complaint against thee? Thus he who looks not on vanity is not perturbed; but he who looks upon it is perturbed, and that, too, all to no purpose.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:18
verses.text: Is it not a vain thing to heap up riches? for surely to seek for fleeting things is vain enough.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:19
verses.text: And when thou hast gathered them, how dost thou know that thou shalt have them in possession?  252.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:20
verses.text: Is it not vain for a merchant to journey by night and by day, that he may be able to heap up treasures? Is it not vain for him to gather merchandise, and to be much perturbed about its price, for fear he might sell it for less than he gave? that he should strive everywhere for high prices, and thus unexpectedly call up robbers against himself through their envy at his much-vaunted business; or that, without waiting for calmer winds, impatient of delays, he should meet with shipwreck whilst seeking for gain?  253.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:21
verses.text: And is not he, too, perturbed in vain who with great toil amasses wealth, though he knows not what heir to leave it to? Often and often all that an avaricious man has got together with the greatest care, his spendthrift heir scatters abroad with headlong prodigality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:22
verses.text: The shameless prodigal, blind to the present, heedless of the future, swallows up as in an abyss what took so long to gather.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:23
verses.text: Often, too, the desired successor gains but envy for his share of the inheritance, and by his sudden death hands over the whole amount of the succession, which he has hardly entered upon, to strangers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:24
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:25
verses.text: Why, then, dost thou idly spin a web which is worthless and fruitless? And why dost thou build up useless heaps of treasures like spiders' webs? For though they overflow, they are no good; nay, they denude thee of the likeness of God, and put on thee the likeness of the earthy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:26
verses.text: If any one has the likeness of the tyrant, is he not liable to condemnation? Thou layest aside the likeness of the Eternal King, and raisest in thyself the image of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:27
verses.text: Rather cast out of the kingdom of thy soul the likeness of the devil, and raise up the likeness of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:28
verses.text: Let this shine forth in thee; let this glow brightly in thy kingdom, that is, thy soul, for it destroys the likeness of all vices.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:29
verses.text: David says of this: "O Lord, in Thy kingdom thou bringest their images to nothing".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 49:30
verses.text: For when the Lord has adorned Jerusalem according to His own likeness, then every likeness of the adversary is destroyed.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:1
verses.text: Chapter L.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:2
verses.text: The Levites ought to be utterly free from all earthly desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:3
verses.text: What their virtues should be on the Apostle's own showing, and how great their purity must be.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:4
verses.text: Also what their dignity and duty is, for the carrying out of which the chief virtues are necessary.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:5
verses.text: He states that these were not unknown to the philosophers, but that they erred in their order.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:6
verses.text: Some are by their nature in accordance with duty, which yet on account of what accompanies them become contrary to duty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:7
verses.text: From whence he gathers what gifts the office of the Levites demands.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:8
verses.text: To conclude, he adds an exposition of Moses' words when blessing the tribe of Levi.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:10
verses.text: If, then, in the Gospel of the Lord the people themselves were taught and led to despise riches, how much more ought ye Levites no longer to be bound down by earthly desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:11
verses.text: For your portion is God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:12
verses.text: For when their earthly possessions were portioned out by Moses to the people of our fathers, the Lord suffered not the Levites to have a share in that earthly possession, for He Himself would be the strength of their inheritance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:13
verses.text: Wherefore David says: "The Lord is the portion of mine inheritance and of my cup".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:14
verses.text: Whence we get the name "Levite," which means: "Himself is mine," or "Himself for me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:15
verses.text: Great, then, is his honour, that God should say of him: Himself is Mine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:16
verses.text: Or, as was said to Peter about the piece of money found in the fish's mouth: "Give to them for Me and for thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:17
verses.text: Wherefore the Apostle, when he said: "A bishop should be sober, modest, of good behaviour, given to hospitality, apt to teach, not covetous, nor a brawler, one that rules well his own house," also added: "Likewise must the deacons be grave, not double-tongued, not given to much wine, not greedy of filthy lucre, holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:18
verses.text: And let them also first be proved, and so let them serve, being found blameless".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:19
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:20
verses.text: We note how much is required of us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:21
verses.text: The minister of the Lord should abstain from wine, so that he may be upheld by the good witness not only of the faithful but also by those who are without.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:22
verses.text: For it is right that the witness to our acts and works should be the opinion of the public at large, that the office be not disgraced.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:23
verses.text: Thus he who sees the minister of the altar adorned with suitable virtues may praise their Author, and reverence the Lord Who has such servants.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:24
verses.text: The praise of the Lord sounds forth where there is a pure possession and an innocent rule at home.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:26
verses.text: But what shall I say about chastity, when only one and no second union is allowed? As regards marriage, the law is, not to marry again, nor to seek union with another wife.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:27
verses.text: It seems strange to many why impediment should be caused by a second marriage entered on before baptism, so as to prevent election to the clerical office, and to the reception of the gift of ordination; seeing that even crimes are not wont to stand in the way, if they have been put away in the sacrament of baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:28
verses.text: But we must learn, that in baptism sin can be forgiven, but law cannot be abolished.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:29
verses.text: In the case of marriage there is no sin, but there is a law.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:30
verses.text: Whatever sin there is can be put away, whatever law there is cannot be laid aside in marriage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:31
verses.text: How could he exhort to widowhood who himself had married more than once?  258.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:32
verses.text: But ye know that the ministerial office must be kept pure and unspotted, and must not be defiled by conjugal intercourse; ye know this, I say, who have received the gifts of the sacred ministry, with pure bodies, and unspoilt modesty, and without ever having enjoyed conjugal intercourse.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:33
verses.text: I am mentioning this, because in some out-of-the-way places, when they enter on the ministry, or even when they become priests, they have begotten children.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:34
verses.text: They defend this on the ground of old custom, when, as it happened, the sacrifice was offered up at long intervals.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:35
verses.text: However, even the people had to be purified two or three days beforehand, so as to come clean to the sacrifice, as we read in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:36
verses.text: They even used to wash their clothes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:37
verses.text: If such regard was paid in what was only the figure, how much ought it to be shown in the reality! Learn then, Priest and Levite, what it means to wash thy clothes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:38
verses.text: Thou must have a pure body wherewith to offer up the sacraments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:39
verses.text: If the people were forbidden to approach their victim unless they washed their clothes, dost thou, while foul in heart and body, dare to make supplication for others? Dost thou dare to make an offering for them?  259.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:40
verses.text: The duty of the Levites is no light one, for the Lord says of them: "Behold I have taken the Levites from among the children of Israel, instead of every first-born that openeth the matrix among the children of Israel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:41
verses.text: These shall be their redemption, and the Levites shall be Mine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:42
verses.text: For I hallowed unto Me all the first-born in the land of Egypt".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:43
verses.text: We know that the Levites are not reckoned among the rest, but are preferred before all, for they are chosen out of all, and are sanctified like the firstfruits and the firstlings which belong to the Lord, since the payment of vows and redemption for sin are offered by them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:44
verses.text: "Thou shalt not receive them," He says, "among the children of Israel, but thou shalt appoint the Levites over the tabernacle of testimony, and over all the vessels thereof, and over all things that belong to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:45
verses.text: They shall bear the tabernacle and all the vessels thereof, and they shall minister in it, and shall encamp round about the tabernacle.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:46
verses.text: And when the tabernacle setteth forward the Levites shall take it down, and when the camp is pitched they shall set up the tabernacle again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:47
verses.text: And the stranger that cometh nigh shall surely be put to death".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:48
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:49
verses.text: Thou, then, art chosen out of the whole number of the children of Israel, regarded as the firstfruits of the sacred offerings, set over the tabernacle so as to keep guard in the camp of holiness and faith, to which if a stranger approach, he shall surely die.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:50
verses.text: Thou art placed there to watch over the ark of the covenant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:51
verses.text: All do not see the depths of the mysteries, for they are hid from the Levites, lest they should see who ought not to see, and they who cannot serve should take it up.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:52
verses.text: Moses, indeed, saw the circumcision of the Spirit, but veiled it, so as to give circumcision only in an outward sign.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:53
verses.text: He saw the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth; he saw the sufferings of the Lord, but he veiled the unleavened bread of truth in the material unleavened bread, he veiled the sufferings of the Lord in the sacrifice of a lamb or a calf.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:54
verses.text: Good Levites have ever preserved the mystery entrusted to them under the protection of their own faith, and yet dost thou think little of what is entrusted to thee? First, thou shalt see the deep things of God, which needs wisdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:55
verses.text: Next, thou must keep watch for the people; this requires justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:56
verses.text: Thou must defend the camp and guard the tabernacle, which needs fortitude.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:57
verses.text: Thou must show thyself continent and sober, and this needs temperance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:58
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:59
verses.text: These chief virtues, they who are without have recognized, but they considered that the order resting on society was higher than that resting on wisdom; though wisdom is the foundation, and justice the building which cannot stand unless it have a foundation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:60
verses.text: The foundation is Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:61
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:62
verses.text: First stands faith, which is a sign of wisdom, as Solomon says, in following his father: "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:63
verses.text: And the law says: "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God, thou shalt love thy neighbour".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:64
verses.text: It is a noble thing to do one's kindnesses and duties towards the whole of the human race.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:65
verses.text: But it is ever most seemly that thou shouldst give to God the most precious thing thou hast, that is, thy mind, for thou hast nothing better than that.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:66
verses.text: When thou hast paid thy debt to thy Creator, then thou mayest labour for men, to show them kindness, and to give help; then thou mayest assist the needy with money, or by some duty, or some service that lies in the way of thy ministry; by money to support him; by paying a debt, so as to free him that is bound; by undertaking a duty, so as to take charge of a trust, which he fears to lose, who has put it by in trust.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:67
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:68
verses.text: It is a duty, then, to take care of and to restore what has been entrusted to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:69
verses.text: But meanwhile a change comes, either in time or circumstances, so that it is no longer a duty to restore what one has received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:70
verses.text: As, for instance, when a man demands back his money as an open enemy, to use it against his country, and to offer his wealth to barbarians.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:71
verses.text: Or, if thou shouldst have to restore it, whilst another stood by to extort it from him by force.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:72
verses.text: If thou restore money to a raving lunatic when he cannot keep it; if thou give up to a madman a sword once put by with thee, whereby he may kill himself, is it not an act contrary to duty to pay the debt? Is it not contrary to duty to take knowingly what has been got by a thief, so that he who has lost it is cheated out of it?  264.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:73
verses.text: It is also sometimes contrary to duty to fulfil a promise, or to keep an oath.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:74
verses.text: As was the case with Herod, who swore that whatever was asked he would give to the daughter of Herodias, and so  allowed the death of John, that he might not break his word.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:75
verses.text: And what shall I say of Jephthah, who offered up his daughter in sacrifice, she having been the first to meet him as he returned home victorious; whereby he fulfilled the vow which he had made that he would offer to God whatever should meet him first.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:76
verses.text: It would have been better to make no promise at all, than to fulfil it in the death of his daughter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:77
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:78
verses.text: Ye are not ignorant how important it is to look to this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:79
verses.text: And so a Levite is chosen to guard the sanctuary, one who shall never fail in counsel, nor forsake the faith, nor fear death, nor do anything extravagant, so that in his whole appearance he may give proof of his earnestness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:80
verses.text: For he ought to have not only his soul but even his eyes in restraint, so that no chance mishap may bring a blush to his forehead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:81
verses.text: For "whosoever looketh on a woman to desire her hath already committed adultery with her in his heart".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:82
verses.text: Thus adultery is committed not only by actual committal of the foul deed, but even by the desire of the ardent gaze.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:83
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:84
verses.text: This seems high and somewhat severe, but in a high office it is not out of place.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:85
verses.text: For the grace of the Levites is such that Moses spoke of them as follows in his blessing: "Give to Levi his men, give Levi his trusted ones, give Levi the lot of his inheritance, and his truth to the holy men whom they tempted in temptation, and reviled at the waters of contradiction.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:86
verses.text: Who said to his father and mother, I know thee not, and knew not his brethren, and renounced his children.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:87
verses.text: He guarded Thy word and kept Thy testimony".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:88
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:89
verses.text: They, then, are His men, His trusty ones, who have no deceit in their hearts, hide no treachery within them, but guard His words and ponder them in their heart, as Mary pondered them; who know not their parents so as to put them before their duty; who hate the violators of chastity, and avenge the injury done to purity; and know the times for the fulfilling of their duty, as also which duty is the greater, which the lesser, and to what occasion each is suited.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:90
verses.text: In all this they follow that alone which is virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:91
verses.text: And who, where there are two virtuous duties, think that which is the more virtuous must come first.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:92
verses.text: These are in truth rightly blessed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:93
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book I 50:94
verses.text: If any one makes known the just works of the Lord, and offers Him incense, then: "Bless, O Lord, his strength; accept the work of his hands," that he may find the grace of the prophetic blessing with Him Who liveth and reigneth for ever and ever, Amen.
